Text: "Why is it that flowers always grow so nicely for Mary? I often plant seeds, but nothing comes from them. They won't grow for me. But blossoms seem to spring right up wherever she goes. They must have a particular liking for her." That's what Tom said, one day, as he saw Mary watering the flowers. Well, it is no wonder, Tom, if flowers do have a liking for such a lovable little girl. There's nothing so very strange about that. How could they help liking her? But, after all, perhaps the secret of the matter is, that Mary loves the flowers, and never forgets to take care of them. She looks after them every day, and not by fits and starts, as some people do. So she has good luck with her flowers and is always able to make up a nice bouquet. And she not only enjoys the flowers herself but, what is better still, she takes delight in having others enjoy them with her. She does not forget to send a liberal share to the Flower Mission; and many a poor sufferer has been cheered by the sight of Mary's flowers.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Narrative format is much easier for students to comprehend. Relatively few complex words and sentences. The topic is easily relatable for the student. Just a few unusual words, but the student can use context clues to decode.

ss_annotator_2: Too many breaks within the sentences - harder to follow the flow

ss_annotator_3: Most sentences are simple or compound, with a few compound-complex sentences. The narrative is clear, action sequences are easy to follow, and vocabulary is familiar, making it accessible for Grade 3 students. Some longer sentences with multiple clauses may need minor teacher guidance to ensure comprehension.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
The catbird belongs to the family of thrushes, and is one of the most peculiar of our American birds. It is dark colored, with brown head and neck, and greenish-black tail. The bird is fond of society, and usually builds its nest near the dwellings of men, rather than in the quiet of the forest.
Its voice, when angry or disturbed, is harsh and shrill, but at other times, soft and sweet. It has also a cry like the mewing of a cat, from which it derives its name. It is very courageous, and will defend its young until it falls exhausted.
The catbird can be tamed, but is as mischievous as a young monkey,—meddlesome, full of curiosity, and so jealous, that it will drive any other pet bird out of the house. It dislikes to be caged, preferring the freedom of the room, so that it may look in the looking-glass, take pins off from the cushion, or perch on the plants in the window.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: While the topic as accessible to 3rd grade students, birds, there are quite a few difficult vocabulary word choices: peculiar, society, shrill, mischievous, looking-glass, perch. There is also a typographical error in the first sentence of the third paragraph, which inhibits comprehension. Rather than saying, "The bird is fond of society," a more kid-friendly version would be, "A catbird is a social animal that prefers to be in the company of other creatures." Some arcane references that students may not be familiar include taking pins off from the cushion.

ss_annotator_2: Vocabulary is too advanced despite mix of simple and complex sentences

ss_annotator_3: Most sentences are simple or compound, with some compound-complex sentences. The passage is descriptive but clear, and ideas are logically sequenced, making it accessible for Grade 3 students. Some sentences with multiple clauses or advanced vocabulary (meddlesome, peculiar, derive) may require teacher support for full comprehension.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
The match is made. The towering pine which listened to the whisper of the south wind and swayed in the cold northern blast has been so divided that we can take it bit by bit and lightly twirl it between two fingers. But what it has lost in size it has gained in use. The little flame it carries, and which looks so harmless, flashing into brief existence, has a latent power more terrible than the whirlwind which perhaps sent the tall pine-tree crashing to the ground.
But the story is not yet closed. From the machine which completed the matches, they are taken to the "boxers"—mostly girls and women—who place them in little boxes. The speed with which this is done is surprising. With one hand they pick up an empty case and remove the cover, while with the other they seize just a sufficient number of matches, and by a peculiar shuffling motion arrange them evenly, then—'t is done!
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Overly symbolic language and unusual anthropomorphizing of trees and wood. Students will have no idea what is going on in this passage. There are also many typographical errors present.

ss_annotator_2: Too hard for 3rd grader to navigate the sentences

ss_annotator_3: Many sentences are long, with multiple clauses, participial phrases, and descriptive modifiers. While the content is engaging, the complexity of sentence structure is likely too challenging for independent reading at Grade 3. Teacher support would be needed to help students parse the sentences and understand the narrative.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: This text is good for 3rd graders- however much of the vocab used is very complex. They likely would pause several times throughout in order to understand many of the vocab words used. The majority of the text would still be understood

vocab_annotator_2: This passage is more appropriate for 4th grade.

vocab_annotator_3: Difficult wording that would be too hard for a student to follow. They wouldn't know at the end what you were even talking about. Matches to a child are a game where you find the same pair.
Tier 2 Words: arrange, bit, completed, divided, existence, harmless, latent, match, peculiar, seize, shuffling, sufficient, swayed, terrible, towering, twirl, whirlwind
Other Complex Words: tightly twirl it between two fingers, boxers
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic concepts of manufacturing and assembly lines, but may not be familiar with the historical context of match production or the specific roles of workers in factories.

Text:
It is important to remember that, in strictness, there is no such thing as an uneducated man. Take an extreme case. Suppose that an adult man, in the full vigor of his faculties, could be suddenly placed in the world, as Adam is said to have been, and then left to do as he best might. How long would he be left uneducated? Not five minutes. Nature would begin to teach him, through the eye, the ear, the touch, the properties of objects. Pain and pleasure would be at his elbow telling him to do this and avoid that; and by slow degrees the man would receive an education, which, if narrow, would be thorough, real, and adequate to his circumstances, though there would be no extras and very few accomplishments.
And if to this solitary man entered a second Adam, or, better still, an Eve, a new and greater world, that of social and moral phenomena, would be revealed.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Complex vocabulary, symbolic language, and overall topic are not comprehensible for children of this age.

ss_annotator_2: Mostly complex sentences with difficult vocabulary

ss_annotator_3: The passage includes a mix of simple, complex, and compound-complex sentences. While some sentences are straightforward, the longer, multi-clause sentences (#3 and #7) and abstract ideas make it challenging for Grade 3 students to read independently. Teacher support would be needed to help students understand the sentence structure and vocabulary.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: The vocab is too challenging for a 3rd grader. The student would have a really hard time understanding what the sentences are saying due to the language that is used. The highlighted vocab is too challenging as well due to the lack of context clues around it. 

vocab_annotator_2: There are too many higher leveled ideas in this passage

vocab_annotator_3: I cannot imagine a text for a 3rd grader that discusses Adam learning of pain and pleasure.

Text: You, on the other hand, have labored in a private way. I have wrought in the day – you in the night. I have had the applause of the crowd and the satisfaction that comes of being approved by the multitude, while the most that you have done has been witnessed by a few trembling, scarred, and foot-sore bondmen and women, whom you have led out of the house of bondage, and whose heartfelt, "God bless you," has been your only reward. The midnight sky and the silent stars have been the witnesses of your devotion to freedom and of your heroism. Excepting John Brown – of sacred memory – I know of no one who has willingly encountered more perils and hardships to serve our enslaved people than you have. Much that you have done would seem improbable to those who do not know you as I know you. It is to me a great pleasure and a great privilege to bear testimony for your character and your works, and to say to those to whom you may come, that I regard you in every way truthful and trustworthy.

Text:
The Roman poet Ovid gives us a connected narrative of creation. Before the earth and sea and the all-covering heaven, one aspect, which we call Chaos, covered all the face of Nature,-- a rough heap of inert weight and discordant beginnings of things clashing together. As yet no sun gave light to the world, nor did the moon renew her slender horn month by month,-- neither did the earth hang in the surrounding air, poised by its own weight,--nor did the sea stretch its long arms around the earth. Wherever there was earth, there was also sea and air. So the earth was not solid nor was the water fluid, neither was the air
transparent. God and Nature at last interposed and put an end to this discord, separating earth from sea, and heaven from both. The fiery part, being the lightest, sprang up, and formed the skies; the air was next in weight and place. The earth, being heavier, sank below, and the water took the lowest place and buoyed up the earth.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The majority of the text consists with sentences that are complex and contain multiple concepts.

ss_annotator_2: The text structure is very complex. It is well written but too much for third or fourth grade.  The additional text in the complex sentences and subordinate clauses are not easy to follow. Students would not be able to follow the flow. The concepts are too vague in thought. They use so many literary elements that make it beautiful- but too much for either grade level.

ss_annotator_3: Vocabulary is too complicated to be able to follow the passage in addition to the complexity of the sentences
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text: One says to me, "I wonder that you do not lay up money; you love to travel; you might take the cars and go to Fitchburg today and see the country." But I am wiser than that. I have learned that the swiftest traveller is he that goes afoot. I say to my friend, Suppose we try who will get there first. The distance is thirty miles; the fare ninety cents. That is almost a day's wages. I remember when wages were sixty cents a day for laborers on this very road. Well, I start now on foot, and get there before night; I have travelled at that rate by the week together. You will in the meanwhile have earned your fare, and arrive there some time tomorrow, or possibly this evening, if you are lucky enough to get a job in season. Instead of going to Fitchburg, you will be working here the greater part of the day. And so, if the railroad reached round the world, I think that I should keep ahead of you; and as for seeing the country and getting experience of that kind, I should have to cut your acquaintance altogether.

ss_annotator_1: The majority of the text consists of complex sentences that contain multiple concepts.

ss_annotator_2: Although there are complex sentences and subordinate clauses that add additional concepts- they are all relevant and add to the content of the story. They are necessary, not just added for effect. This is a good third grade book.

ss_annotator_3: Too many breaks and concepts within the sentences - hard to follow

vocab_annotator_2: Challenging topic for understanding

Text: Louis Bonaparte has never been other than a man who has lain wait for fortune, a spy trying to dupe God. He had that livid dreaminess of the gambler who cheats. Cheating admits audacity, but excludes anger. In his prison at Ham he only read one book, "The Prince." He belonged to no family, as he could hesitate between Bonaparte and Verhuell; he had no country, as he could hesitate between France and Holland. This Napoleon had taken St. Helena in good part. He admired England. Resentment! To what purpose? For him on earth there only existed his interests. He pardoned, because he speculated; he forgot everything, because he calculated upon everything. What did his uncle matter to him? He did not serve him; he made use of him. He rested his shabby enterprise upon Austerlitz. He stuffed the eagle. Malice is an unproductive outlay. Louis Bonaparte only possessed as much memory as is useful. Hudson Lowe did not prevent him from smiling upon Englishmen; the Marquis of Montchenu did not prevent him from smiling upon the Royalists.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The text consists of a majority of simple sentences and sentences with one concept.

ss_annotator_2: Although there are several simple sentences, I believe it is a good fit for third grade. Some of the sentences offer enough complexity with additional concepts to make it more difficult. The sentence starting with,  "He belonged" has the most complexity which is why this is good for third grade and not to easy.

ss_annotator_3: Vocabulary and sentence structure not 3rd grade level

Text:
We went from the path through the forest: a whole flock of bare-headed boys surrounded us. They would all be our guides; the one screamed longer than the other, and every one gave his contradictory explanation, how high the water stood, and how high it did not stand, or could stand. There was also a great difference of opinion amongst the learned.
We soon stopped on a ling-covered rock, a dizzying terrace. Before us, but far below, was the roaring water, the Hell Fall, and over this again, fall after fall, the rich, rapid, rushing elv--the outlet of the largest lake in Sweden. What a sight! what a foaming and roaring, above--below! It is like the waves of the sea, but of effervescing champagne--of boiling milk. The water rushes round two rocky islands at the top so that the spray rises like meadow dew. Below, the water is more compressed, then hurries down again, shoots forward and returns in circles like smooth water, and then rolls darting its long sea-like fall into the Hell Fall. What a tempest rages in the deep--what a sight! Words cannot express it!
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The majority of the text is complex sentences that contain more than one concept.

ss_annotator_2: Wow! This is a lot! I love the transitions and how they are used to develop the story, but it has far too many detailed subordinate clauses and complex sentences for third grade.

ss_annotator_3: Vocabulary and sentence structure not 3rd grade level

vocab_annotator_1: The large number of tier 2 words makes this text too difficult for the grade level. Students would likely have difficulty comprehending the text without additional instruction.

vocab_annotator_2: This passage is more appropriate for 4th grade.

vocab_annotator_3: Very confusing to read this!

Text:
May I say a few words? I want to say a few words about this matter.
I am a woman's rights.
I have as much muscle as any man, and can do as much work as any man.
I have plowed and reaped and husked and chopped and mowed, and can any man do more than that?
I have heard much about the sexes being equal; I can carry as much as any man, and can eat as much too, if I can get it.
I am as strong as any man that is now.
As for intellect, all I can say is, if women have a pint and man a quart — why can't she have her little pint full?
You need not be afraid to give us our rights for fear we will take too much, for we can't take more than our pint'll hold.
The poor men seem to be all in confusion, and don't know what to do.
Why children, if you have woman's rights, give it to her and you will feel better.
You will have your own rights, and they won't be so much trouble. 
I can't read, but I can hear.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Multiple complex sentences with more than one concept.

ss_annotator_2: Most of this text is very simple. It does contain some elements of complexity in the addition of some subordinate clauses or additional concepts to make it a good fit.

ss_annotator_3: Easy to follow
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Although the tier 2 and tier 3 words are related to the topic, the large number of metaphors and imagery make this text too difficult for the grade level without teacher instruction. Several phrases are archaic and would also impact understanding.

vocab_annotator_2: This passage is appropriate for 3rd grade.

Text:
It is natural to believe in great men. If the companions of our childhood should turn out to be heroes, and their condition regal, it would not surprise us. All mythology opens with demigods, and the circumstance is high and poetic; that is, their genius is paramount. In the legends of the Gautama, the first men ate the earth, and found it deliciously sweet.
Nature seems to exist for the excellent. The world is upheld by the veracity of good men: they make the earth wholesome. They who lived with them found life glad and nutritious. Life is sweet and tolerable only in our belief in such society; and actually, or ideally, we manage to live with superiors. We call our children and our lands by their names. Their names are wrought into the verbs of language, their works and effigies are in our houses, and every circumstance of the day recalls an anecdote of them.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Far too complex and abstract for elementary aged children. Everything about this is not accessible to children. Difficult vocabulary: companions, regal, demigods, circumstance, paramount, Gautama, upheld, veracity, nutritious, tolerable, ideally, superiors wrought, effigies, anecdote.

There is also a heavy usage of commas for nonrestrictive/parenthetical elements and semicolons, neither of which 3rd graders would have learned to use. The Flesch Kincaid level denotes a text complexity suitable for 4th-5th grade.

Text:
Fortuny won his own opportunities. He took a prize, while still very young, which made it possible for him to go to Rome where he wished to study art. He did not spend his time studying and copying the old masters as did most artists who went there, but, instead, he studied the life of the Roman streets.
He had already been at the Academy of Barcelona, but he did not follow his first master; instead, he struck out a line of art for himself. After a year in Rome the artist went to war; but he did not go to fight men, he was still fighting fate, and his weapon was his sketch book. He went with General Prim, and he filled his book with warlike scenes and the brilliant skies of Morocco. From that time his work was inspired by his Moorish experiences.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Although only sentences 2 and 5 are complex or compound-complex, there are several subordinate phrases or clauses and/or transition words in sentences 2, 3, 4, 5, and 7; two of these sentences have semicolons. Also, sentences 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 contain multiple concepts, meaning only two sentences (1 and 7) have single concepts. Third graders learn to use linking words and phrases in their writing, and identify words related to text structures, such as time order and sequences, in their reading. These skills will help them decipher the subordinate phrases/clauses and transition words in this text. However, with most of the sentences having 2-3 concepts, it will still be too difficult for most 3rd graders to tackle on their own. Since the sentences were not "mainly" complex, the text could not be rated Exceedingly Complex, but since there were so many subordinate phrases, transitions, and concepts, it could also not be rated Moderately Complex. The Flesch Kincaid level, based on average sentence and word lengths, rates this text as appropriate for grades 6-8.

ss_annotator_2: The passage has some very simple sentences. However it does also have added complexities in the additional concepts added through subordinate clauses or complex sentences. The transition words are very helpful to allow the reader to flow through the story.

ss_annotator_3: More complex sentence structure but easier vocabulary

vocab_annotator_2: This passagem is more appropiate for 4th grade students.

vocab_annotator_3: Difficult to follow but able to be done if you go slowly.

Text:
Italian painters received their names in peculiar ways. This man's father was a tailor; and the artist was named after his father's profession. He was in fact "the Tailor's Andrea," and his father's name was Angelo.
One story of this brilliant painter which reads from first to last like a romance has been told by the poet, Browning, who dresses up fact so as to smother it a little, but there is truth at the bottom.
Andrea married a wife whom he loved tenderly. She had a beautiful face that seemed full of spirituality and feeling, and Andrea painted it over and over again. The artist loved his work and dreamed always of the great things that he should do; but he was so much in love with his wife that he was dependent on her smile for all that he did which was well done, and her frown plunged him into despair.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: This text only has 2 complex sentences; however, several simple and compound sentences have subordinate clauses, transitions, and/or multiple concepts. For instance, 3 of the 7 sentences have subordinate clauses, transitions, and multiple concepts, with 2 sentences containing multiple subordinate clauses. Most of the sentences contain 2 or more concepts, which increase the complexity, and some of the sentences are also very long, which is reflected in the 8.59 Flesch Kincaid score. The only reason the text is not Exceedingly Complex is because the majority of the sentences are simple and compound, not complex.

ss_annotator_2: While there are a few simple sentences, there are also complex sentences and subordinate clauses that add additional concepts to the story. This text has a good balance of simple and complex for ta third grade.

ss_annotator_3: Mix of simple and complex with navigatable vocabulary
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored

Text:
Credit and credit cards are special types of loans. When you use a credit card to buy things, instead of paying for them immediately, each purchase goes onto a big list. At the end of the month, the credit card company adds everything on the list together and sends you a one bill for the total amount of money you spent that month.
The special feature of credit cards is that you do not have to pay back the entire bill right then. Imagine you spent $5,000 last month. When you get the bill, you might only have to use your $1,000 to pay the bill, but you still have all $5,000 worth of stuff you bought.
This functions as a loan because the credit card company has, in a round-about way, loaned you that leftover $4,000. As with a loan, you will still have to pay that $4,000 back eventually, and the credit card company will charge you interest on it. So, in the end, you might owe $4,500 (plus the $1,000 you used to pay the minimum part of the original bill).
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: This text consists of a majority of complex sentences (5/9), which increases the complexity. Seven of the sentences contain at least one subordinate clause, 6 include transition words, and 5 of the sentences contain 2 concepts each. By definition, the text is Exceedingly Complex. The Flesch Kincaid score of 7.03 denotes a text complexity of 4th-5th grade, which would be above grade level.

ss_annotator_2: There are simple and complex sentences, however the complex sentence structure is not difficult. It adds to the meaning of the sentence so it makes it easier to read.  The transitions in the text are helpful to move through the passage. This does not provide enough rigor for third grade.

ss_annotator_3: Mix of simple and complex with navigatable vocabulary
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Students might not have background knowledge on interest, but I think most proficient third graders will be able to get the gist from the passage.

vocab_annotator_2: Defining the individual terms in this passage is not complex. However, the domain knowledge and associated math skills required to understand the words and what they mean add some complexity. 

vocab_annotator_3: Very easy to follow and great examples for a student to read.

Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic concepts of money and spending but may not be familiar with credit, loans, or interest.

Text:
Teresa was born in 1910 in a town called Skopje, then part of the Ottoman Empire, today the capital city of Macedonia. She always loved to hear stories about missionaries working to help people in different countries around the world. She was active in the Catholic church for her whole life, and when she was 18 years old she moved to an Abbey in Ireland to learn English and train to be a missionary.
Mother Teresa's given name was Anjezë Gonxhe Bojaxhiu; she picked the name Teresa for herself after she moved to India in 1929. She completed her training as a nun while teaching at St. Teresa's school, which was near her convent. When she took her religious vows in 1931, she chose to be named after Therese de Lisieux, the patron saint of missionaries.
She later moved to Calcutta, India, to teach at the Loreto Convent school. She enjoyed the job but was often disturbed by the suffering and violence she saw in the streets of Calcutta. She wondered what she could do to help.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Although 6 of the 9 sentences are simple or compound, 5 sentences contain subordinate clauses, 7 contain transition words, and 7 contain multiple concepts. Two of those 7 sentences even contain 3 concepts each. The only reason it is not Exceedingly Complex is that it does not consist mainly of complex sentences. The Flesch Kincaid score indicates that it is a good fit for the 6th-8th grade text complexity band.

ss_annotator_2: The transition words are helpful to follow the timeline given in the text. This text has just a bit too much complexity for third grade. The complex sentences and subordinate clauses are meaningful and relevant, but a few of the sentences are more than a third grade text should have.

ss_annotator_3: Mix of simple and complex with navigatable vocabulary
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: I don't think your average third grader would have the background to comprehend the geography and the terms that would be more familiar to students that practice the Christian religion

vocab_annotator_3: unfamiliar words to some kids such as nun, Catholic but some students would understand it from their upbringing.

Text:
The sun is a star, just like the other millions of stars you see when you look at the night sky. In fact, the sun is a relatively normal star. Like all stars, it is a large ball of gas that produces huge amounts of energy. Stars form when particles floating in space are drawn closer together by gravity, until the cloud of space dust is round and dense. Inside that dense center, hydrogen atoms are under so much pressure that they fuse together into helium atoms. This process is called nuclear fusion, and it releases a lot of extra energy in the forms of heat and light. Nuclear fusion is what keeps stars burning.
4.5 billion years ago, when the sun formed, it was not the only clump of gas and dust swirling around space. As the sun's particles pulled together, other particles and clouds farther away began circling around it, too. Those clouds started condensing into planets. The process was dramatic. Clumps of space dust slammed into each other, breaking apart and reforming, over millions of years.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: This passage has a lot of simple sentences. There are enough complex sentences to make it more difficult. The additional concepts that are added are additive in nature and helps the reader better understand the content. The transition words are also helpful but not too guided for a third grade student.

ss_annotator_2: Mix of simple and complex with navigatable vocabulary

ss_annotator_3: The passage primarily uses clear and direct sentences, with a few complex sentences that include subordinate clauses and participial phrases. Most Grade 3 students should be able to read and understand the text with minimal support, though they may need guidance on parsing longer sentences and some scientific vocabulary.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored

Text:
"Well, then," said the teacher, "you may take your slate and go out behind the schoolhouse for half an hour. Think of something to write about, and write the word on your slate. Then try to tell what it is, what it is like, what it is good for, and what is done with it. That is the way to write a composition."
Henry took his slate and went out. Just behind the schoolhouse was Mr.
Finney's barn. Quite close to the barn was a garden. And in the garden,
Henry saw a turnip.
"Well, I know what that is," he said to himself; and he wrote the word turnip on his slate. Then he tried to tell what it was like, what it was good for, and what was done with it.
Before the half hour was ended he had written a very neat composition on his slate. He then went into the house, and waited while the teacher read it.
The teacher was surprised and pleased. He said, "Henry Longfellow, you have done very well. Today you may stand up before the school and read what you have written about the turnip."
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Easily relatable and comprehensible topic. Simple text and sentence structures. Children might not know what a slate is, but they can infer and determine what it is based on the context.

ss_annotator_2: Mix of simple and complex with navigatable vocabulary

ss_annotator_3: The passage primarily uses clear and concise sentences, with a few compound or complex sentences. Most Grade 3 students should be able to read and understand the story independently, and the simple narrative with dialogue supports comprehension.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Straight forward, easy to comprehend. The words slate and composition make it so that is isn't too easy

vocab_annotator_3: Easy to follow and understand.
Tier 2 Words: composition, schoolhouse, surprised, turnip
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic writing exercises and the concept of writing compositions, but they may not be familiar with historical figures like Henry Longfellow or the historical context of one-room schoolhouses.

Text:
A great violinist, Ole Bull by name, visited the Grieg family in the country. He was so kind to the little composer that the boy just loved him.
Ole Bull had traveled the world over playing the violin. He looked over Edvard's compositions and made the boy play them to him. You can see him nodding his head in pleasure as he listens. His fine eyes are lighted up. He tells the boy composer that his music is quite good, but that there is a lot for him to learn yet. So he must study earnestly and make many sacrifices.
Then Ole Bull sits down and talks with Father and Mother Grieg. It is a serious talk, as one can see. Finally, when the talk is finished, Ole Bull takes the wondering boy by the hand and says to him:
"You are going to Leipzig to study and become a fine musician."
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Easily understandable story about the childhood of Edvard Grieg. Students are able to use context clues to understand words like earnestly.
ss_annotator_2: Mix of simple and complex with navigable vocabulary
ss_annotator_3: The passage primarily uses simple and compound sentences, with some complex sentences. Most Grade 3 students should be able to read and understand it with minimal support. The narrative is clear, the vocabulary is accessible, and the dialogue and story structure help maintain comprehension.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Most men do their best work in their younger years, but in Haydn's later years he wrote two of his greatest works: The Creation and The Seasons. The Creation is loved by all people. It is one of a group of favorite oratorios which have found a warm place in the hearts of the people. With it stand The Messiah, Judas Maccabaeus, St. Paul and Elijah. Do you know who composed each of these?
After the English journeys, Haydn lived quietly in Vienna in what is now known as the Haydn house. Should you ever go to Vienna you will be welcomed there by the caretaker, who will show you the rooms in which Haydn lived.
One day toward the end of his life he asked his servant to carry him to the piano. While the members of his household stood near him he played three times, very solemnly, the Emperor's Song.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: I dislike how it asks a question but does not answer it. This could easily be done and would clarify things for the reader. What are the English journeys? This feels like there are pieces of information that should have been included. Unclear pronouns in the final paragraph.
ss_annotator_2: Mix of simple and complex with navigable vocabulary
ss_annotator_3: The passage includes mostly simple sentences, with some compound and complex sentences. Most Grade 3 students should be able to read and understand it with minimal support. The clear narrative structure, short paragraphs, and familiar context (music, historical figures) help maintain comprehension. Complex sentences with subordinate clauses may require occasional guidance.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored

Text:
Some day the operas of Richard Wagner will give you great pleasure. At first they were not liked by the public. Wagner had few friends and his life was very hard. But Franz Liszt believed in him and in his work. And so he helped him.
At first Wagner did not like Liszt. He once said, "I never repeated my first call on Liszt." By this he meant that he wished the acquaintance to end. When Liszt realized that Wagner did not care to understand him, he tried his best to keep the friendship secure. Liszt never wished to misunderstand another human being. So, it was not long before Wagner's opinion of Liszt changed, for he said, later, "Through the love of this rarest friend I gained a real home for my art."
There is one thing true for us all. We carry our early thoughts along with us all through life. The friends we make from youth and the thoughts we think from youth are always at hand to bless us if we have done wisely.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The first paragraph is appropriate, but the second becomes very challenging. The sentence structures of paragraphs two and three are too confusing. The abstract nature of the message in the final paragraph will not make sense to most elementary aged children.
Only a few difficult vocabulary words (acquaintance, secure, misunderstand) but the way the sentences are composed make it quite challenging.
ss_annotator_2: Mix of simple and complex with navigable vocabulary
ss_annotator_3: The passage uses mostly simple sentences with some compound and complex sentences. The narrative is clear and chronological, which helps Grade 3 students follow the story. Dialogue and familiar concepts like friendship and perseverance make comprehension easier. Some complex sentences with subordinate clauses may require teacher support.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Some of the dialogue won't be familiar to third graders as it's not the same phrasing we would use today, but I do think that most proficient third graders can derive the main point
vocab_annotator_2: This text is an independent task for 3rd grade students.
vocab_annotator_3: Some tier 2 words might be difficult for a reader but overall the text is appropriate.

Text:
Richard Wagner's day of birth was May 22, 1813. That was more than a century ago! More than twelve hundred months!
Since that time, music has changed very greatly. When Wagner was born, much of the music that was being written had to follow certain patterns or models just as architects follow certain patterns in building a house. Now the composer when he writes music feels a great deal freer as he knows that he can make his own patterns, that he is not held in by any such hard laws as those which held back such composers as Mozart, Bach, Haydn and Handel. It was Wagner who did much to set music free from the old barriers. This does not mean that music today is better than music that was written by Haydn and Beethoven. Indeed it often is not nearly so good, but it is freer, less held down by rule.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Why would you say day of birth rather than birthday? No need to say twelve hundred months - that is as abstract as the word a century to a child. Complex vocabulary words: architects, freer, barriers. Seems 
This is unfamiliar content to the vast majority of students and unnecessarily convoluted in the syntax of the sentences and word choice.
ss_annotator_2: Mix of simple and complex with navigable vocabulary
ss_annotator_3: The passage includes long sentences with multiple clauses and abstract concepts about music history and composition. Comparisons to architects and references to older composers may be difficult for Grade 3 students to grasp fully. Some vocabulary (e.g., “composer,” “patterns,” “barriers”) could be unfamiliar. While parts of the text are concrete, the overall sentence structure and conceptual depth make it above typical Grade 3 expectations.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: The text and vocab is appropriate for a 3rd grader. Majority of the vocab are names, which would not cause the student to lose track of the most important points if they need to pause to comprehend the pronunciation or meaning of hte names. The other vocab words (tier 2) will be able to be solved as well without the major points of the story being missed. 
vocab_annotator_2: No passage showing....
vocab_annotator_3: The topic of this passage may not be familiar to the students, but the style is easy to read and straight forward. The vocabulary are words that third graders have seen before, so that shouldn't be too difficult.

Text: The public buildings and gardens were worthy of the first city in Europe. With some of the travelers of today are familiar. The larger number of the remarkable churches now standing were in existence before the Revolution. Of the palaces then in the city, the three most famous have met with varied fates. The Luxembourg, which was the residence of the king's eldest brother, is the least changed. To the building itself but small additions have been made. Its garden was and is a quiet, orderly place where respectable family groups sit about in the shade. The Louvre has been much enlarged. Under Louis XVI. it consisted of the buildings surrounding the eastern court, of a wing extending toward the river (the gallery of Apollo), and of a long gallery, since rebuilt, running near the riverbank and connecting this older palace with the Tuileries. About one-half of the space now enclosed between the two sides of the enormous edifice, and known as the Place du Carrousel, was then covered with houses and streets. The land immediately to the east of the Tuileries palace was not built upon, but part of it was enclosed by a tall iron railing.

The structure of the text is informational and dense, requiring a strong understanding of historical context and spatial descriptions, which is beyond typical Grade 3 sentence comprehension.

Text: At this time there began to be much talk about a voyage of exploration to that country which Leif had discovered. The leader of this expedition was Thorstein Ericsson, who was a good man and an intelligent, and blessed with many friends. Eric was likewise invited to join them, for the men believed that his luck and foresight would be of great furtherance. He was slow in deciding, but did not say nay, when his friends besought him to go. They thereupon equipped that ship in which Thorbiorn had come out, and twenty men were selected for the expedition. They took little cargo with them, naught else save their weapons and provisions. On that morning when Eric set out from his home, he took with him a little chest containing gold and silver; he hid this treasure, and then went his way.

Text:
The island is called Cuba. It belongs to a large group of islands known as the West Indies; a changed form of the old name, West Indias, given by Christopher Columbus, who thought that by sailing westward he had reached islands off the shore of India. If you look on a map of the Western Hemisphere, you will find the West Indies between the Caribbean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean.
Most of these islands are high and rocky, seeming like a chain of mountains in the ocean, with their tops above the waves. They are in the tropical regions, and the climate is very hot in the lowlands and on the coasts, but is delightful in the high parts all the year round. There are only two seasons—wet and dry. The rainy season begins in the spring or early summer, and lasts about six months.
What grows in these islands? Delicious fruits: mangoes, oranges, cocoanuts, limes, pineapples, and bananas; many other valuable crops: coffee, tobacco, maize, rice, sugar-cane, and cotton; immense forests of mahogany and other valuable trees. This beautiful vegetation makes these lands fair to look upon. Then, too, there are many birds with gorgeous plumage.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The passage contains some long and informational sentences with multiple clauses (e.g., the first sentence about Christopher Columbus). While many sentences are straightforward, the historical reference and geographic vocabulary (“Western Hemisphere,” “West Indies”) may be difficult for typical Grade 3 students. They could understand the main idea with teacher guidance or visual support like maps and pictures.
ss_annotator_2: While it is made up of mostly simple sentences, many of them have multiple concepts making it tricky or hard for the average 3rd grader.
ss_annotator_3: Good mix of sentence types
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: some complex vocab that is specific to the subject and somewhat academic. for a 4th grade reader, this would likely be accessible for comprehension and reading given in-text definitions and mostly approachable/relatable content
vocab_annotator_2: The number of unfamiliar vocabulary words will likely prevent this student from understanding the passage.
vocab_annotator_3: The style of this writing is straight forward and students are used to this style. The complex words are proper nouns that a third grader would be able to figure out. There is a lot of vocabulary, but this third grade student with this Flesch Kincaid score would be able to use context clues to help them with understanding.
Tier 2 Words: belongs, delightful, gorgeous, immense, plumage, vegetation
Tier 3 Words: caribbean, christopher columbus, climate, cuba, hemisphere, mahogany, maize, mangoes, sugar cane, tropical, west indies
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic geography concepts, such as maps and the Western Hemisphere, and may have some knowledge of Christopher Columbus. They are less likely to be familiar with the specific geography and climate of the West Indies or the detailed agricultural products of the region.

Text: The Times' gentleman (a very difficult gent to please) is the loudest and noisiest of all, and has made more hideous faces over the refreshment offered to him than any other critic. There is no use shirking this statement! when a man has been abused in the Times, he can't hide it, any more than he could hide the knowledge of his having been committed to prison by Mr. Henry, or publicly caned in Pall Mall. You see it in your friends' eyes when they meet you. They know it. They have chuckled over it to a man. They whisper about it at the club, and look over the paper at you. My next-door neighbor came to see me this morning, and I saw by his face that he had the whole story pat. "Hem!" says he, "well, I HAVE heard of it; and the fact is, they were talking about you at dinner last night, and mentioning that the Times had—ahem!—'walked into you.'"
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The sentence structure is complex, with many clauses, parenthetical comments, and embedded dialogue. The passage assumes knowledge of social and historical context (e.g., Pall Mall, caning, clubs, newspapers) that a typical Grade 3 student would likely not understand. Even with scaffolding, students would struggle to follow the flow and nuance of the sentences.
ss_annotator_2: Most of the sentences are easy to decode and comprehend, but there are also a few that are challenging. Making it in my opinion appropriate for the grade
ss_annotator_3: Error in sentence 2-3 (statement! when). Too many concepts per sentence, especially in sentences 2-3
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: It's not the complexity of the vocabulary, but the use of too many archaic words and phrases that will keep students from understanding
vocab_annotator_2: The number of unfamiliar words, combined with the historical context will likely cause this student to glean very little.
vocab_annotator_3: This is a dated text as a 9 year old won't know what "looking over the paper" is a newspaper and even then that's unknown for kids. Pall Mall? Smoking is not common to 9 year olds in a social way.

Text:
On the farms utensils and furniture were generally made in the household. Almost everything was made of wood, as spoons, tankards, pails, firkins, hinges for cupboard and closet doors, latches, plows, and harrows. Every boy learned to use his jack-knife, and could make brooms from birch trees, bowls and dippers and bottles from gourds, and butter paddles from red cherry. The women made soap and candles, carded wool, spun, wove, bleached or dyed the linen and woolen cloth, and made the garments for the family. They knit mittens and stockings, made straw hats and baskets, and plucked the feathers from live geese for beds and pillows.
On the farms the houses of the early settlers were of logs, or were framed structures covered with shingles or clapboards. The tables, chairs, stools, and bedsteads were of the plainest sort, and were often made of puncheons, that is, of small tree trunks split in half. Sometimes the table would be a long board laid across two X supports. This was "the board," around which the family sat at meals. In the better houses in the towns the furniture was of course very much finer.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The passage contains long, information-dense sentences with multiple clauses and lists of objects and actions (e.g., all the wooden utensils and household tasks). While the language is mostly concrete, the length and complexity of the sentences may overwhelm a typical Grade 3 reader. With teacher guidance, students could grasp the main ideas, but independent comprehension would be difficult.
ss_annotator_2: These sentences contain multiple concepts and ideas. There are lists, concepts and multiple ideas that can get confusing for the students to recall.
ss_annotator_3: While otherwise not overly complex, there is an excessive use of lists that make the text clunky for grade 3
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Too challenging for 3rd grade. One again, an overload of new vocabulary. Too many unknowns and making connections ... even when they learn the words ... would be time consuming. I believe this would effect the overall understanding of the passage. This might be a 4th grade, perhaps 5th grade passage. It is a lot of information that would need to be understood within a context.
vocab_annotator_2: With this many tier 2, 3, archaic, and complex words, this student will not comprehend very much of the passage.
vocab_annotator_3: The style of the writing is straight forward with information. A third grader is familiar with this style of writing. The vocabulary, especially the Tier 3 words, archaic and complex words would be challenging for a third grader, however, with this Flesch Kincaid score, they should be able to use context clues to help them with understanding.

Text: Every log in my house is as straight as a pine can grow. Each room has a window and a door on the east side, and the south room has two windows on the south with space between for my heater, which is one of those with a grate front so I can see the fire burn. It is almost as good as a fireplace. The logs are unhewed outside because I like the rough finish, but inside the walls are perfectly square and smooth. The cracks in the walls are snugly filled with "daubing" and then the walls are covered with heavy gray building-paper, which makes the room very warm, and I really like the appearance. I had two rolls of wallpaper with a bold rose pattern. By being very careful I was able to cut out enough of the roses, which are divided in their choice of color as to whether they should be red, yellow, or pink, to make a border about eighteen inches from the ceiling. Text: Every log in my house is as straight as a pine can grow. Each room has a window and a door on the east side, and the south room has two windows on the south with space between for my heater, which is one of those with a grate front so I can see the fire burn. It is almost as good as a fireplace. The logs are unhewed outside because I like the rough finish, but inside the walls are perfectly square and smooth. The cracks in the walls are snugly filled with "daubing" and then the walls are covered with heavy gray building-paper, which makes the room very warm, and I really like the appearance. I had two rolls of wallpaper with a bold rose pattern. By being very careful I was able to cut out enough of the roses, which are divided in their choice of color as to whether they should be red, yellow, or pink, to make a border about eighteen inches from the ceiling. They brighten up the wall and the gray paper is fine to hang pictures upon. Those you have sent us make our room very attractive.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Fourth graders can generally handle compound and complex sentences and more detailed descriptive text. The passage offers multiple clauses and rich details, which provide both challenge and opportunity for vocabulary development. Students may need minimal guidance with less common terms, but the content is suitable for independent reading with some attention to sentence parsing.

ss_annotator_3: About half complex and half simple. Seems ok for 4th

Text: The usual dimensions of a cabin were sixteen by twenty feet. The timber for the building, having been already cut, lay at hand—logs of hickory, oak, young pine, walnut, or persimmon. To make the foundations, the men seized four of the thickest logs, laid them in place, and notched and grooved and hammered them into as close a clinch as if they had grown so. The wood must grip by its own substance alone to hold up the pioneer's dwelling, for there was not an iron nail to be had in the whole of the Back Country. Logs laid upon the foundation logs and notched into each other at the four corners formed the walls; and, when these stood at seven feet, the builders laid parallel timbers and puncheons to make both flooring and ceiling. The ridgepole of the roof was supported by two crotched trees and the roofing was made of logs and wooden slabs. The crevices of the walls were packed close with red clay and moss. Lastly, spaces for a door and windows were cut out.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The passage includes long, multi-clause sentences with advanced vocabulary such as “clinched,” “puncheons,” “ridgepole,” and “crotched.” The descriptive technical details about building a cabin require higher-order comprehension skills that are typically beyond independent Grade 3 reading. Students at this level would likely need guided support to understand the sequence of construction and the specialized terms.
ss_annotator_2: The sentence structure is too complex for an average third grader. They have not worked much (if any) with participial phrases or compound-complex sentences.
ss_annotator_3: Mostly complex sentence constructions. With vocab too tough for grade level
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Although students will be introduced to lots of new vocabulary as long as they have background knowledge of a rustic cabin they should be able to infere the meaning
vocab_annotator_2: The lack of historical knowledge combined with the quantity of complex vocabulary will be problematic for this 3rd graders.
vocab_annotator_3: The topic of this passage is one that would interest a third grader. The style is straight forward and third graders are familiar with this style of writing. The vocabulary would be challenging for a third grader, but with their Flesch Kincaid score, this third grader should be able to comprehend.

Text: It has never been explained why Jefferson Davis was chosen President of the Confederacy. He did not seek the office and did not wish it. He dreamed of high military command. As a study in the irony of fate, Davis's career is made to the hand of the dramatist. An instinctive soldier, he was driven by circumstances three times to renounce the profession of arms for a less congenial civilian life. His final renunciation, which proved to be of the nature of tragedy, was his acceptance of the office of President. Indeed, why the office was given to him seems a mystery. Rhett was a more logical candidate. And when Rhett, early in the lobbying at Montgomery, was set aside as too much of a radical, Toombs seemed for a time the certain choice of the majority. The change to Davis came suddenly at the last moment. It was puzzling at the time; it is puzzling still.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The passage contains abstract concepts (irony of fate, renunciation, congenial, tragedy) and assumes background knowledge of historical figures and the Confederacy. The sentence structures are complex, with multiple clauses, parenthetical asides, and elevated vocabulary. These elements make the text too difficult for typical Grade 3 students to comprehend independently.
ss_annotator_2: This passage has a lot of complex and compound sentences with multiple concepts making it difficult for a third grader to comprehend.
ss_annotator_3: Mostly complex constructions. Some complex vocab too -- too difficult for 3rd.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Too many archaic and tier 3 words that students would have no schema built to use for comprehension
vocab_annotator_2: This passage is too sophisticated, clunky, and confusing for the average third-grader. I believe students would feel overwhelmed by it
vocab_annotator_3: This passage is written in a style that a third grader is used to reading, but there is a lot of vocabulary that third graders haven't been exposed to which would make this passage quite difficult to complete independently.
Tier 2 Words: acceptance, arms, candidate, career, chosen, civilian, confederacy, congenial, dreamed, driven, explained, fate, instinctive, irony, lobbying, logical, majority, military, mystery, office, profession, puzzling, radical, renounce, renunciation, seek, tragedy
Tier 3 Words: arms, circumstances, confederacy, congenial, dramatist, instinctive, irony, lobbying, profession of arms, puzzling, radical, renounce, renunciation, reunciation

Text:
Sir Hubert Gough's army was sent down in January to take over from the French a sector forty to fifty miles long. Clearly such a line as this could be held only if it were strongly located and cunningly constructed, and there is no doubt that it was. Three lines were designed: First, an outpost line, then a "line of resistance," and then a "battleline." The outpost line was designed with special care. It consisted of a number of separate posts so located as to provide for a cross-fire on any enemy that penetrated them. It was intended to be held until the last gasp, and it was presumed that the Germans might pass through it, but that they would be terribly punished by the garrisons of the isolated posts.
In one way the attack was not a surprise. General Gough had known for days that it was imminent, and had moved his men up to their positions and made every preparation possible. But one thing he could not foresee or guard against—the mist and fog.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The text contains military terminology (e.g., “sector,” “outpost line,” “line of resistance,” “battleline,” “garrisons”), abstract ideas about strategy, and complex sentence structures with multiple clauses. These elements make it difficult for typical Grade 3 students to follow, both in terms of vocabulary and conceptual understanding.
ss_annotator_2: There are multiple sentences that contain multiple concepts. There are complex-compound sentences that can confuse the reader.
ss_annotator_3: Lots of multi-part sentences, and challenging enough vocab to make it more than 3rd grade level.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Words like "garrisons" and "gasp" and some of the phrasing are going to make it too hard, unless the student has more schema with war
vocab_annotator_2: This passage contains too many difficult vocabulary terms, and the entire idea of the passage would be lost. The writing is too archaic to be enjoyed, in this case.
vocab_annotator_3: The style of this writing is straight forward with details and explanation. The topic is not familiar with a third grader, and more background would need to be given, but this third grader with this Flesch Kincaid score should be able to be successful. There is a lot of vocabulary, but again this student should be able to use context clues to help them figure out meaning.

Tier 3 Words: cross-fire, cunningly, garrisons, imminent, intended, isolated, imminent, outpost, sector
Other Complex Words: could not foresee, general, sir, sir hubert gough's, terribly punished
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic concepts of military defense and strategy from historical contexts, but they are not likely familiar with specific World War I military tactics or figures like Sir Hubert Gough.

Text:
Those living on swift streams, and using small boats, often have occasion to tow up stream. So do surveyors, hunters, campers, tourists, and others. One man can tow a boat against a swift current where five could not row.
Where there are two persons, the usual method is for one to waste his strength holding the boat off shore with a pole, while the other tows. Where but one person, he finds towing almost impossible, and when bottom too muddy for poling and current too swift for rowing, he makes sad progress.
The above cut shows how one man can easily tow alone. The light regulating string, B, passes from the stern of the boat to one hand of the person towing, T. The tow line, A, is attached a little in front of the center of the boat. Hence when B is slackened the boat approaches the shore, while a very slight pull on it turns the boat outward. The person towing glances back "ever and anon" to observe the boat's line of travel.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The passage uses technical vocabulary (e.g., “tow,” “stern,” “muddy,” “regulating string”) and detailed procedural descriptions that require abstract reasoning. The multiple clauses and instructions within sentences make it difficult for typical Grade 3 readers to follow without visual aids or teacher guidance.
ss_annotator_2: Based on the sentence structure this passage is appropriate for a third grader. It is comprised of many simple sentences that contain only one concept making it challenging enough for a typical third grader.
ss_annotator_3: Mostly complex constructions. Add to that the vocab and the technicality of the subject, too hard.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: This is a passage that no third-grader should have to endure. It is clumsy, it circumvents the actual ideas, and is almost impossible to visualize.
vocab_annotator_2: The style the author uses in this passage in not easily read by a third grader. There are some sentence starters that would not be familiar to students, which would make comprehension difficult to understand. There is a lot of vocabulary that a third grader has not seen in text and would have difficulty understanding.

Tier 3 Words: poling, regulating, slackened, stern, surveyors, tow line
Archaic Words: ever and anon, hence, often have occasion
Other Complex Words: ever and anon, poling, swift streams, the repeated use of the word "one"
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic concepts of force and motion, as well as the use of simple machines like pulleys, but may not be familiar with specific techniques for towing boats or the challenges of navigating swift streams.

Text:
Carver knew that certain plants put nutrients back into the soil. One of those plants is the peanut! Peanuts are also a source of protein.
Carver thought that if those farmers planted peanuts, the plants would help restore their soil, provide food for their animals, and provide protein for their families — quite a plant! In 1896 peanuts were not even recognized as a crop in the United States, but Carver would help change that.
Carver told farmers to rotate their crops: plant cotton one year, then the next year plant peanuts and other soil-restoring plants, like peas and sweet potatoes. It worked! The peanut plants grew and produced lots of peanuts. The plants added enough nutrients to the soil so cotton grew the next year. Now the farmers had lots of peanuts — too many for their families and animals — and no place to sell the extras. Again, Carver had a plan. Do you know what he did?
Carver invented all kinds of things made out of peanuts. He wrote down more than 300 uses for peanuts, including peanut milk, peanut paper, and peanut soap.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: This text structure  is moderately complex. Any additional concepts add to the meaning so they are helpful. There are some complex sentences and subordinate clauses which create the rigor needed for third grade. The transitions are helpful, but appropriate.
ss_annotator_2: The sentence structure is clear and mostly simple, with some compound sentences. Concepts are concrete (peanuts, soil, crops) and familiar enough for Grade 3 students. The text includes some transitional words (“but,” “then,” “again”), which support comprehension. Occasional questions directed at the reader add engagement without overcomplicating the sentence structure.
ss_annotator_3: This passage is appropriate for a third grader. It is comprised of mostly simple sentences with only one concept. The sentences that are multi-conceptual contain ideas that are easy to comprehend.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Seems straightforward and easy to comprehend
vocab_annotator_2: This passage is nearly perfect for a third-grader. Its subject matter is interesting, and the sentence structure, including the use of questions, renders it very accessible. 
vocab_annotator_3: Contains science terms that push students  vocabulary development. 
 
 Uses some domain-specific Tier 3 words. 
 
 Overall: manageable with context clues and teacher guidance.
Tier 2 Words: crop, including, invented, nutrients, potatoes, produced, protein, provide, recognized, restore, rotate, source
Tier 3 Words: cotton, crop, farmers, peanuts, soil, soil-restoring, sweet potatoes
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic plant needs and growth, as well as the concept of nutrients and protein. They may not be familiar with crop rotation, soil restoration, or George Washington Carver's contributions to agriculture.

Text: I have here in a test tube some water in which a small piece of meat was placed a few days ago. The test tube has been in rather a warm room, and the meat has begun to decompose. What has here taken place is the first step in this inquiry. This has been the question at which scientific men have been working, and from the study of which has come a valuable addition to surgical knowledge associated with the name of Professor Lister, and known as antiseptic. What happens to this meat, and what is going on in the water which surrounds it? How long will it be before all the smell of putrefaction has gone and the water is clear again? For it does in time become clear, and instead of the meat we find a fine powdery substance at the bottom of the test tube. It may take weeks before this process is completed, depending on the rate at which it goes on.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: I like this text complexity for third! It introduces new concepts and the additional complexity in subordinate clauses or compound nature add more detail to gain more depth. It flows logically and the transitions are too obvious.
ss_annotator_2: The sentence structure is complex, with long sentences, multiple clauses, and scientific vocabulary (e.g., “decompose,” “putrefaction,” “antiseptic”) that may be difficult for a typical Grade 3 reader to follow. Some sentences combine multiple ideas, requiring higher inferential skills. While the overall concept could be understood with guidance, independent reading would likely be challenging.
ss_annotator_3: The sentences are genuinely easy to follow even though they are compound with multiple concepts. They can challenge the students but for the most part it is appropriate to grade 3.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Procure a straight piece of wood about ¼ inch wide by 1/8 inch thick and 13 inches long. Beginning ½ inch from the end, bore a row of small holes only large enough for a darning needle to pass through and half an inch apart. Mark the first one (at A) 0, the third 1, the fifth 2, and so on to 12, so that the numbers represent the distance from O in inches. A small slit may be made in the end of the ruler or strip of wood near A, but a better plan is to attach a small clip on one side.
Next procure a strong piece of linen thread about four feet long; pass it through the eye of a coarse needle, wax and twist it until it forms a single cord. Pass the needle upward through the hole marked 0, and tie a knot in the end of the thread to prevent its slipping through. The apparatus is now ready for immediate use. It only remains to set it to the size of the oval desired.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: This text would require students to stay focused to follow the path of the concepts. It is a good fi to get stronger at text complexity. There are multiple steps within a sentence which give an appropriate amount of rigor, but the transitions make it manageable. Good text for following directions.
ss_annotator_2: The passage contains long, multi-step instructions with precise measurements, fractions, and specialized terms (e.g., “darning needle,” “linen thread,” “wax and twist”). Many sentences are compound or complex and describe sequential steps that require careful attention. Grade 3 students might struggle with both the technical vocabulary and the multi-step reasoning needed to follow the directions independently.
ss_annotator_3: There are many challenging concepts including participial phrases, and complex-compound sentences. Due to these higher level concepts I believe it is too hard for a third grader.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Most third graders could comprehend this, even though it is technical and uses some vocab specifc directions
vocab_annotator_2: This passage would be difficult for third-graders to comprehend, given the abstract nature of the concepts and the lack of easy visual clues. It rambles, and is thoroughly unenjoyable.
vocab_annotator_3: The author uses notation in this passage that would make this difficult for a third grader. This third grader would have to be proficient in context clues to figure out meaning of many of these vocabulary words. This text would be too difficult for this third grader.
Tier 2 Words: attach, bore, coarse, darning needle, linen, oval, prevent, procure, represent
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic measurement and simple tools like rulers, but may not be familiar with the specific process of creating a measuring apparatus or the use of terms like "procure" and "bore."

Beginning ½ inch from the end, bore a row of small holes only large enough for a darning needle to pass through and half an inch apart. A small slit may be made in the end of the ruler or strip of wood near A, but a better plan is to attach a small clip on one side.
Next procure a strong piece of linen thread about four feet long; pass it through the eye of a coarse needle, wax and twist it until it forms a single cord. Pass the needle upward through the hole marked 0, and tie a knot in the end of the thread to prevent its slipping through. The apparatus is now ready for immediate use. It only remains to set it to the size of the oval desired.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: For the same reasons this is a good text for fourth. The depth of concepts told through a complex sentence will provide enough rigor. It might get a bit easier by the end of fifth, but I like it for a midway point.
ss_annotator_2: Fourth graders are generally better equipped to handle multi-step instructions and measurements, though fractions and precise measurements may still require guidance. The sentence structure is complex but manageable for students with some experience in procedural texts. With scaffolding or teacher support, a Grade 4 student could understand the procedure and the purpose of the steps.
ss_annotator_3: Again, there are some simple straightforward sentences, but there are also many compound and complex sentences with multi-concepts. Thus, making it too challenging for an average fourth grader.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Helen Adams Keller was born on 27th June 1880, in Tuscumbia, Alabama, United States. Her family lived on an estate called Ivy Greens, built by Helen's grandfather. Her father, Arthur Keller, spent many years as an editor for the Tuscumbia North Alabamian newspaper, and had served as a captain in the Army. Her mother, Kate Adams, was the daughter of a confederate general. Helen was born with the ability to see and hear. At 19 months old, she became ill, and this illness left Helen both deaf and blind.
As she grew up, she found a way of communicating with the daughter of the family's cook; Martha Washington. They invented a kind of sign language and by the time Helen was 7 years old they had created more than 60 different signs for use in their personal communication.
Around this time, Helen became very frustrated and diffcult to control. She had violent temper tantrums and would giggle uncontrollably when she was happy. Her family was worried about Helen and went in search of help. Unaware of how to deal with Helen's disabilities, the family had indulged , which at this point it was to her detriment.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Good fit!  The complex text elements add details that will enhance a third grade understanding of the concepts being presented. It is a more mature text and the students would appreciate and enjoy that.  The transitions are helpful to understand the timeline being explained. They get bored with simple text structure- so this is great!
ss_annotator_2: The text uses some advanced vocabulary (e.g., confederate general, indulged, detriment), as well as longer, complex sentences. The biography structure, however, is familiar and interesting for this age group, especially with the dramatic change in Helen Keller’s life at 19 months. Third graders could follow the story but may need support in understanding certain terms and historical references.
ss_annotator_3: There are many straightforward sentences that just give factual information. Even if there are multiple concepts, they are easy to follow. The last few sentences are more challenging, which is why I believe it is appropriate for a third grader
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text: In many industries there are operations that have to be repeated at regular intervals, and, for this reason, the construction of an apparatus for giving a signal, not only at the hour fixed, but also at equal intervals, is a matter of interest. The question of doing this has been solved in a very elegant way by Mr. Silas in the invention of the apparatus. It consists of a clock whose dial is provided with a series of small pins. The hands are insulated from the case and communicate with one of the poles of a pile contained in the box. The case is connected with the other pole. A small vibrating bell is interposed in the circuit. If it be desired to obtain a signal at a certain hour, the corresponding pin is inserted, and the hand upon touching this closes the circuit, and the bell rings. The bell is likewise inclosed within the box. There are two rows of pins--one of them for hours, and the other for minutes. They are spaced according to requirements.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: These are largely simple sentences and singular concepts- but the first sentence enhances the passage. This allows it to be appropriate for third. Without that sentence I would say the ext complexity would be too easy.
ss_annotator_2: Justification: The sentences in this passage are very long, technical, and heavily dependent on multiple clauses (e.g., “The hands are insulated from the case and communicate with one of the poles of a pile contained in the box.”). Third graders are still developing comfort with compound sentences and would find the scientific language (apparatus, insulated, circuit, corresponding, requirements) plus the sentence length overwhelming. The structure is not grade-appropriate for independent reading at Grade 3. It would require teacher scaffolding, breaking down sentences, and simplifying vocabulary.
ss_annotator_3: The first sentence alone proves to be too difficult for a third grader. It has multiple concepts, multiple clauses and multiple transitions. The structure of the sentences are also not commonly seen and can be proven tricky as well.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
The Germans have made a routine of their attacks, always making them at night and always ineffectually. They advance as far as the barbed wire, 30 yards in front of the trench. There they encounter the full force of the Russian rifle fire and fall back again. The Germans shell without ceasing. All the Russians speak of their profuse expenditure of ammunition. The commander of the trench told me that at the lowest they fired over 3,000 shells on a single day.
Although intermittent firing continued through the night, no attack was made. With the morning the German guns resumed their exhaustive questing along the rear of the trenches, and a big factory to the southward once more became their target. Its great chimney began to acquire a kind of sporting significance, it was so obviously the object of fire in that direction; and bets were going in the trench backing the chimney against the German gunners.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: This text is too difficult due to the multiple complex sentences with multiple clauses. Students at this age have not been exposed to sentences with semi colons too often.
ss_annotator_2: Sentences are long, compound/complex, and contain advanced descriptive phrasing (“their exhaustive questing along the rear of the trenches”).
ss_annotator_3: Many sentences have multiple concepts. The sentences that are simple have concepts that are well above grade level, which would impede on the students' comprehension.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
The day of a definite victory has not yet come. Our task until then will be heavy, and it may be long. Let us bring all our strength to bear in the carrying out of this task. Our allies know that we will do so, as well as the neutral nations, and it is in vain that a wild campaign of false news has been set on foot. If Germany at the outset pretended to have any doubt as to the attitude of France, she no longer doubts.
Let Germany bear witness now that when the French Parliament reopened after over four months of war, it has renewed before the world the spectacle it offered on the day when, in the name of the nation, it took up the challenge.
To conquer, heroism at the frontier will not suffice. It is necessary also to have internal union. Let us continue to preserve this sacred union from any blemish today, as in the past, and in the future. Let us keep before our minds the one cry of victory, the vision of our motherland, and the ideal of right.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Although the sentences are shorter, it contains many complex sentence structures and embedded clauses which make it very difficult for students at this age.
ss_annotator_2: Sentences are long, formal, and abstract (“it is in vain that a wild campaign of false news has been set on foot”).
ss_annotator_3: While there are mostly simple, single conceptual sentences. Many contain transitions that are not as common so more tricky to find. Additionally, the multi-conceptual sentences have multiple concepts, clauses and transitions.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: this text includes mostly complex vocabulary (tier 2) with some academic and archaic terms. this text is likey too difficult for a 3rd grade reader as the sentence structure, complex vocabulary and a lack of context of the historical meaning would make htis too difficult to comprehend as an independent reader
vocab_annotator_2: This passage would be more appropriate for a fifth-grader. Younger students would find this difficult to understand, especially the old-fashioned vocabulary.
vocab_annotator_3: Passage is hard to follow as an adult. Students will have a hard time with this due to vocabulary and lack of background knowledge.
