Tier 3 Words: attitude of france, heroism, internal union, motherland, parliament, she no longer doubts, spectacle, suffice, vision of our motherland

Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with the concept of alliances and conflicts from studying communities and environments, but they may not be familiar with the specific historical context of World War I or the political dynamics between France and Germany.

Text: The brilliant little scarlet berries of this plant render it, when well grown, one of the prettiest of ornaments for the hothouse, conservatory, or even for a warm room. It is quite easily managed, stray seeds of it even growing where they fall, and making handsome specimens. For indoor decoration few subjects are more interesting, and a few plants may be so managed as to have them in fruit in succession all the year round. Any kind of soil will answer for this Rivina. Cuttings of it strike freely, but it is easiest obtained from seeds. Either one plant or three may occupy a 6 in. pot, and that is the best size for table decoration. Usually it is best to raise a few plants every year and discard the old stock, but some may be retained for growing into large specimens. These should be cut back before they are started into growth. The berries yield a fine, but fugitive red color.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: This text is too advanced for a 3rd grader because of the sentence length and structure using many phrase and clause types which make it harder to follow.
ss_annotator_2: Sentences are long and multi-clausal (“For indoor decoration few subjects are more interesting, and a few plants may be so managed as to have them in fruit in succession all the year round”).
ss_annotator_3: The overall structure of the first sentence would make this above a third grader's ability. This sentence is complex and has multiple clauses, concepts and phrases. The second sentence is compound-complex and has multiple concepts as well as a participal phrase.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text: Take whale oil. Take the funny old buildings on Front Street, out of paintings, I declare, by Howard Pyle, where the large merchants in whale oil are. Take salt fish. Do you know the oldest salt-fish house in America, down by Coenties Slip? Ah! you should. The ghost of old Long John Silver, I suspect, smokes an occasional pipe in that old place. And many are the times I've seen the slim shade of young Jim Hawkins come running out. Take Labrador cod for export to the Mediterranean lands or to Porto Rico via New York. Take herrings brought to this port from Iceland, from Holland, and from Scotland; mackerel from Ireland, from the Magdalen Islands, and from Cape Breton; crabmeat from Japan; fishballs from Scandinavia; sardines from Norway and from France; caviar from Russia; shrimp which comes from Florida, Mississippi, and Georgia, or salmon from Alaska, and Puget Sound, and the Columbia River.

There are many long, complex sentences and frequent uses of a semicolon.
ss_annotator_3: There are multiple complex sentences that have multiple clauses. Additionally the way the words are structured in the sentences are not typical and can confuse a third grader.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Have you heard of the World Wide Web? No? Never mind. Now, have you heard of the Internet? Yes? Great! But what IS the Internet? Did you say "I am not quite sure, but I know it has something to do with computers"? You're right – it does. But that's not the whole answer. What's the WHOLE answer then? Hmmm. We need an EXPERT to answer that. And guess what - I know JUST the person! She's usually to be found near a computer, so let's go straight to the computer now.
Hi Nettikutti! Here is a group of kids to meet you! Come on out, come on out, wherever you are! THERE you are! Go on, kids, say hello! And don't be fooled by her cuteness and her size – she holds a LOT of information in her little head!
So Nettikutti, here's what everyone wants to know - What IS the Internet? Ooooh. BIG question. Let's see how I can put it simply. The Internet (short for ‘INTERconnected NETworks') is a large, large, LARGE collection of computers from all over the world that are connected to each other.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: This text is very appropriate for a third grader because of the short sentences and repetition. The passage sounds more like a conversation which makes it engaging and easy to follow
ss_annotator_2: There's a lot going on in this passage. It's like a conversation with a lot of punctuation.  There is a combination of short and long sentences and most of the sentences are simple or compound which is understandable to the grade level.
ss_annotator_3: Most sentences are not only simple, but only one or two words. There are few complex sentences, mostly with simple concepts. The concept is something everyone is familiar with making it easy to comprehend as well.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: this contains some complex vocab but mostly simple words. this text would likely be readable for a 3rd grade reader. 
vocab_annotator_2: This passage is way too easy for third-graders, and it use of capital letters and the word 'ooooh" is very juvenile and patronizing.
vocab_annotator_3: This text was easy to follow with the exception of the words I listed in the complex words (which might be a glitch or error).
Tier 2 Words: collection, connected, connected networks, everyone, expert, information, someting
Tier 3 Words: interconnected networks, internet, world wide web
Other Complex Words: interconnected networks, nettikutti, world wide web
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic computer usage and the concept of the Internet as a tool for accessing information, but they may not be familiar with the technical details of how the Internet functions as interconnected networks.

Text: Our bodies need energy to move and do work. Where do we get our energy from? The energy is obtained from the food that we and all other organisms eat. If you think back to the work you did on fuel and energy in previous grades in Energy and Change, you will remember that fuels, such as wood, coal, and oil, contain chemical potential energy. When this fuel is burned in the presence of oxygen, the chemical potential energy is transferred into light and heat energy. In the same way, the glucose from the food that you eat is combined with oxygen in a series of chemical reactions to release the energy. The glucose is broken down and the energy is released. This energy is then used to drive all the other processes in your body. This process is called respiration. We can define respiration in all living organisms as the process by which energy is released from glucose in a series of chemical reactions. Respiration takes place in all organisms, even plants. However, plants do not need to eat any food as they make their own food during photosynthesis.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The sentences are readable in structure, but  a number are long with clauses. This  may be difficult for a 3rd grader because each sentence has many words and ideas.
ss_annotator_2: This text structure is great for third. It has additional concepts through the structure and concepts, but the transitions guide the reader through them. It is a great example to practice text complexity without it being too difficult.
ss_annotator_3: While there are many simple sentences, many of them are multi-conceptual making it tricky for a third grader. There are also several sentences with relative clauses, something that isn't common in third grade texts so it can impede on their comprehension of the sentences.

vocab_annotator_1: I think this is also too hard for on grade level third graders. Even with a background from a unit about energy and food, this seems too complex. An idea about chemical potential energy is abstract. I understand the repetition, but I don't think it works. Glucose really needs to be explained thoroughly before this passage starts heading into respiration. 
vocab_annotator_2: This passage is a tiny bit complex for the average third-grader, and a thorough review of vocabulary would be necessary before trying to interpret.
vocab_annotator_3: This passage is too complex for a third grade student.

Text: Our bodies need energy to move and do work. Where do we get our energy from? The energy is obtained from the food that we and all other organisms eat. If you think back to the work you did on fuel and energy in previous grades in Energy and Change, you will remember that fuels, such as wood, coal, and oil, contain chemical potential energy. When this fuel is burned in the presence of oxygen, the chemical potential energy is transferred into light and heat energy. In the same way, the glucose from the food that you eat is combined with oxygen in a series of chemical reactions to release the energy. The glucose is broken down and the energy is released. This energy is then used to drive all the other processes in your body. This process is called respiration. We can define respiration in all living organisms as the process by which energy is released from glucose in a series of chemical reactions. Respiration takes place in all organisms, even plants. However, plants do not need to eat any food as they make their own food during photosynthesis.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: A 4th grader could get through this passage, but  not easily as the sentences are long and a bit complex.
ss_annotator_2: I like this for fourth aslo. Although the transitions do not require the rigor, the additional structure and concepts are appropriate at this grade. To make it more difficult toward the end of the year, possibly make the transitions less obvious.
ss_annotator_3: I think that there is a good balance between simple and complex sentences in this passage. I believe it is a somewhat complex, yet appropriate fourth grade passage.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Carbohydrates are the main supply of energy for our bodies. They break down in our digestive system to form glucose (which is a sugar). Examples of foods that contain carbohydrates are: whole grain bread, potatoes, pasta, rice, fruit, vegetables, maize and legumes. Unfortunately many people eat too many carbohydrates, especially processed carbohydrates like sweets and biscuits, chips, pastries, soft drinks and sweetened fruit juices.
Fats and oils are important for many body processes:
• Fat protects and insulates your organs
• They help maintaining healthy hair and nails.
• Some vitamins can only be absorbed and transported when attached to fat molecules.
• Fats and oils also provide the body with energy.
However, some fats are better than others and having too much of any type is not a good idea. Vitamins help with the different chemical reactions in our bodies:
• vitamin A helps strengthen our immune system and is good for eyesight in the dark
• B vitamins help us process energy from food
• vitamin C helps to keep your skin and gums healthy and improves the immune system
• vitamin D helps to build strong bones and teeth
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The sentences are mostly simple or compound  which is good for this age. The bullet points/lists help to keep the reading more on the readable side.
ss_annotator_2: The text structure is simple and uninspiring. However the overall text introduces a lot of concepts. For that reason, I find it appropriate. It would be less enjoyable, however more informative if the purpose was to gather facts. There is a lot to think about so that creates enough rigor.
ss_annotator_3: I think that there are a lot of simple sentences with few multi concepts making it easy for a third grader to comprehend.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Dear Mr. Morse:
It was very pleasant to me to get a letter from you the other day. Perhaps I should have found it pleasanter if I had been able to decipher it. I don't think that I mastered anything beyond the date (which I knew) and the signature (at which I guessed).
There's a singular and perpetual charm in a letter of yours—it never grows old; it never loses its novelty. One can say to one's self every morning: "There's that letter of Morse's. I haven't read it yet. I think I'll take another shy at it today, and maybe I shall be able in the course of a few days to make out what he means by those t's that look like w's, and those i's that haven't any eyebrows."
Other letters are read, and thrown away, and forgotten; but yours are kept forever—unread. One of them will last a reasonable man a lifetime.
Admiringly yours, T.B. Aldrich.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Sentences would be difficult for a 3rd grader . There are a couple of very long, complex sentences and the use of quotes, parenthesis, colons, lots of commas - too much.
ss_annotator_2: The text structure is fairly basic, but I do think the additional clauses and structure offer more depth to the message and emotions of the writer. The letter structure is also a structure of text that is appropriate for third grade.
ss_annotator_3: There are an evenly distributed amount of simple and complex/compound sentences as well as single concept/multi-concept sentences. This makes it challenging, yet still appropriate for third grade.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Acceleration is a measure of how fast velocity changes. Acceleration is the change of velocity divided by the change of time. Acceleration is a vector, and therefore includes both a size and a direction. An object was moving north at 10 meters per second. The object speeds up and now is moving north at 15 meters per second. The object has accelerated.
An apple is falling down. It starts falling at 0 meters per second. At the end of the first second, the apple is moving at 9.8 meters per second. The apple has accelerated. At the end of the second second, the apple is moving down at 19.6 meters per second. The apple has accelerated again.
Jane is walking east at 3 kilometers per hour. Jane's velocity does not change. Jane's acceleration is zero.
Tom was walking east at 3 kilometers per hour. Tom turns and walks south at 3 kilometers per hour. Tom has had a nonzero acceleration.
Sally was walking east at 3 kilometers per hour. Sally slows down. After, Sally walks east at 1.5 kilometers per hour. Sally has had a nonzero acceleration.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The sentences are generally simple sentences.
ss_annotator_2: This text structure is too simple in all ways for third and fourth. While reading it, the flow would be too choppy and that could inhibit their interest and focus. Students would benefit from additional concepts being added to deepen the meaning of the sentence. The transitions are predictable and too simple as well. It has a simple  and uninspiring text structure.
ss_annotator_3: There are a lot of simple sentences and single concept sentences and very few compound/multi-concept sentences. The topic is a little challenging for a third grader that is why. I believe it is appropriate for them
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Algae (one alga, but several algae) are a type of plant-like living things that can make food from sunlight by photosynthesis. The study of algae is called phycology or algology.
The term lumps together many different kinds of organisms. They have in common only that they are autotrophic: they use natural sources of energy and simple inorganic materials to build their forms. As non-vascular plants they do not have the kind of cell and tissue structure of land plants. They are a convenient but very loose term. Only in recent years has it become clear how different the many kinds of algae are.
Algae are a large and diverse group of simple, typically autotrophic organisms. Some have one cell and others have many cells. The largest and most complex marine algae are called seaweeds. They are like plants, and "simple" because they lack the many distinct organs found in land plants. For that reason they are not classified as plants.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: This passage has simple, compound and complex sentences. Third grade would be more comfortable with simple to compound sentences.
ss_annotator_2: This structure has mainly simply complexity. There is very little creativity in the structure- subject- predicate. The small amount of structure and concept complexity helps add detail but it would need more. The repetitive style of each sentence is too basic. It could use some more depth. This is more appropriate for second grade.
ss_annotator_3: While half the sentences are simple, many contain multiple concepts making it difficult to follow, especially if the concept is unknown, as this is to third graders. Many sentences have multiple types of phrases and clauses within, making it challenging for a third grader.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: VCS: The density of Tier 3 words in this text poses significant challenges to comprehension for the average third-grade student reading on grade level. 
vocab_annotator_2: This passage is a bit too complex for third-graders, though not altogether impossible. With thorough review of vocabulary and concepts, students may eventually grasp it.
vocab_annotator_3: The passage would be very difficult for this student. There too many tier 3 words that the student will need to learn before being able to make sense of the material.
Tier 2 Words: classified, convenient, distinct, diverse, energy, inorganic, loose, marine, natural sources, organisms, photosynthesis, recent, the study, typically
Tier 3 Words: algae, algology, autotrophic, cell, inorganic, land plants, marine, non-vascular, non-vascular plants, organisms, photosynthesis, phycology, seaweeds, simple inorganic materials, simple org, tissue
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic plant biology and photosynthesis but may not be familiar with the specific study of algae (phycology) or the classification differences between algae and land plants.

Text: The American Civil War (1861–1865) was a civil war in the United States of America. It is sometimes called "The War Between the States". Eleven Southern states in which slavery was legal wanted to leave the United States of America. They formed the Confederate States of America, also called "the Confederacy". They wanted the Confederate States of America to be its own country, separate and independent from the United States. Jefferson Davis was chosen as president of the Confederacy. The U.S government and the states that remained loyal to it were called the Union. The Union is sometimes called "the North". Every state where slavery was illegal supported the Union. Most of these states were in the North. Five states where slavery was legal also supported the Union. These were called the "border states". War began on April 12, 1861 when Confederate forces attacked Fort Sumter held by a Union garrison.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Text is appropriate and short and direct. The sentences are factual and sequential which make it easier to follow.
ss_annotator_2: Right on for 3rd grade. Sentences are simple and straightforward.
ss_annotator_3: Many of the sentences are simple sentences with just one concept. They have just one clause or phrase, so the sentence structure is easy, but since the concepts are more challenging I believe that it is appropriate for the grade.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Students would be able to access the gist of this text with light to medium scaffolds; vocab is not a insurmountable barrier to comprehension
 
vocab_annotator_2: This is a great passage for third-graders, in that the vocabulary is accessible and the concepts easy to grasp. The sentence structure is just right.
vocab_annotator_3: The content and the vocabulary will likely prevent this student from learning this material.
Tier 2 Words: attacked, border, confederate, illegal, independent, independent. separate, loyal, separate, supported
Tier 3 Words: border states, confederacy, confederate, garrison, union

Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with the basic concept of the Civil War and its significance in U.S. history, but may not be familiar with specific details such as the role of border states or the attack on Fort Sumter.

Text:
It was Bede who identified the invaders as Angles, Saxons and Jutes. But he sometimes used the names Angli and Saxones for the same people in different parts of his writings. In Book I, Chapter 15 he said that by invitation of King Vortigern "Angles or Saxons" came to Britain in three longships. Modern authorities confirm that Angles, Saxons, Frisians and some Jutes did come to England during this migration time period. The differences in England between tribes of Angles and Saxons was not significant. Kent was different in culture from other parts of England, and was home to Jutes. But Kent had later contact with the regions they had come from in Europe and that could explain some of the differences.
Certain styles of jewellery are recognized by archaeologists as being typical of Anglian, Saxon and Jutish areas in Northern Europe. But why the name England came to be used for the country and English for the language is not clear. In Old English the people call themselves Engle. In Latin it was Angli. Nothing suggests the Angles made up a larger percentage of the Germanic peoples.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Some sentences may be challenging due to the different clauses that are in the sentences.
ss_annotator_2: Many of the sentences are too long for a 3rd grader's readability. Many compound and complex sentences make it difficult for 3rd graders.
ss_annotator_3: These sentences have relative clauses, independent and dependent clauses and contain content that is well above a third graders ability.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Imagine that you have a test tomorrow that you need to study for. How much cognitive effort will you put in? Researchers have found that your behavior can be predicted by the calculation of the costs and benefits of studying. What might these costs and benefits be?
To keep it simple, we can say that the benefit of studying is to obtain a good grade. Obtaining a good grade is better for your final report, and you may just like getting good grades. An important cost has to do with the level of cognitive effort you must exert—to obtain a good grade, you will sometimes have to think harder.
Researchers describe your decision to use cognitive effort as a function of the potential benefits and costs. You could think of this as a math equation: the sum of costs and benefits results in a certain value. The more you value something, the more likely you are to put cognitive effort into it.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The text includes a mx of simple and compound sentences. Some of the ideas presented are abstract and may make comprehension challenging. Teacher support would be needed
ss_annotator_2: Sentences have too many words and there are a number of complex sentences - too much for. grade level.
ss_annotator_3: There are multiple complex sentences with multiple concepts. There are not any transitional words or phrases that help the children differentiate them.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Students would be able to access the gist of this text with light to medium scaffolds; vocab is not a insurmountable barrier to comprehension
 
vocab_annotator_2: There are many words that have a different meaning in this text than what they may have already been exposed to. There are also very phonetically complex words that would require more advanced decoding skills. "Cognitive Effort" is way beyond the typical third grade student.
vocab_annotator_3: There are a lot of challengng words for 3rd grade. I wouldn;t say mostly challenging words, but enough for it to be too complex.
Tier 2 Words: behavior, benefits, calculation, certain, cognitive, costs (usage), decision, describe, effort, equation, exert, function, imagine, obtain, potential, predicted, researchers, results, sum, value
Tier 3 Words: cognitive effort, equation, exert, obtain, obtaining, potential, predicted, sum, value
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with the concept of studying for tests and the idea of costs and benefits in simple decision-making. They may not be familiar with the term "cognitive effort" or the idea of quantifying effort as a function of costs and benefits.

Text:
An atom is the basic unit that makes up all matter. There are many different types of atoms, each with its own name, mass and size. These different types of atoms are called chemical elements. The chemical elements are organized on the periodic table. Examples of elements are hydrogen and gold. Atoms are very small, but the exact size changes depending on the element. Atoms range from 0.1 to 0.5 nanometers in width. One nanometer is around 100,000 times smaller than the width of a human hair. This makes atoms impossible to see without special tools. Equations must be used to see the way they work and how they interact with other atoms.
Atoms come together to make molecules or particles: for example, two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom combine to make a water molecule, a form of a chemical reaction.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Sentence structures are mostly manageable for this age, but support may still ne be needed for abstract terms.
ss_annotator_2: Most of the sentences in this text are simple or compound. The majority have one concept , there are a few subordinate clauses , and even fewer transition words or phrases. Third graders have learned to write simple, compound, and complex sentences, so the majority of these sentences should pose little challenge for them. They use linking words and phrases in their own writing, similar to the ones used in this text. The only sentence that could push the text to Very Complex is sentence 11 because it contains 3 concepts and uses a colon, which they have not yet learned to use. The Flesch Kincaid scale places the text at the upper end of the 4th-5th grade band, most likely due to vocabulary (number of syllables per word).
ss_annotator_3: Many of these sentences are simple enough to determine meaning of but there are some challenges that may prove complex for a third grader. I believe that the concepts are simple enough for this to be appropriate for third grade.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: This requires a good deal of scaffolding in order to access the gist and meaning of this text - vocabulary may be a barrier to comprehension. Definitely a stretch text
vocab_annotator_2: Though complex in its subject matter and vocabulary, the passage is designed to fairly easily explain the concepts without losing the reader.
vocab_annotator_3: Lots of challenging words, including academic words
Tier 2 Words: atom, basic, combine, depending, elements, equations, exact, impossible, interact, mass, organized, periodic, range, unit, width
Tier 3 Words: chemical elements, chemical reaction, equations, hydrogen, molecules, nanometers, oxygen, particles, periodic table
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic concepts of matter and atoms, but may not be familiar with the periodic table, nanometers, or the specifics of chemical reactions.

Text:
Did you know that there are mountains two miles below the Arctic Ocean? Scientists are just starting to learn about them. But it isn’t easy.
Scientists can’t travel to this mountain range for three reasons. First, the Arctic Ocean is covered by a thick sheet of ice. Second, the mountains are so deep that divers and even submarines can’t travel there. And third, there is no light. The water is pitch-black.
How do scientists study this place? Special robots help them explore deep below the ocean.
Scientists drop the robots into the water through a hole in the ice. The robots travel to the bottom of the ocean. They take pictures and collect information. Hours later, they find their way back to the hole in the ice so the scientists can pick them up. And they do this all by themselves!
The scientists have learned a lot from the robots. They’ve learned that the mountains are volcanoes. The volcanoes erupt deep under the ocean.
Scientists have also found strange animals there. One is an octopus with flaps on its head. The flaps look like elephant ears.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: This text consists of primarily simple and compound sentences. Of the 6 remaining complex sentences, only 2 have more than one concept, There are also only 4 subordinate/dependent phrases and 6 transition words. Most of the transition words are for sequencing (first, second, third, later), which students learn in second grade. The Flesch Kincaid level places the text within the 2nd-3rd grade text complexity band.
ss_annotator_2: This text structure is too simple for third and fourth. Although it gives a decent amount of content, each sentence only offers one concept. To increase the rigor, additional structure could offer more detailed aspects of the content to develop the depth of the passage. The transitions are very basic. This is the grade to begin enhancing transitional choices. Students appreciate a well developed sentence. These are boring.
ss_annotator_3: The majority of the sentences are either simple, or complex and only have one concept. They are easy for a third grader to comprehend.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Students would be able to access the gist of this text with no to light scaffolds; vocab is not a barrier
 
vocab_annotator_2: This passage is very appropriate for third-graders, in that the sentence structure is easy to follow and the vocabulary is very understandable and explained well.
vocab_annotator_3: This passage seems to be in line with what the student can handle independently.
Tier 2 Words: collect, erupt, explore, information, pitch-black, range, sheet, special, thick, volcanoes
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with ocean/sea exploration and the use of technology like robots for scientific research, but they may not be familiar with the specific challenges of exploring the Arctic Ocean or the concept of underwater volcanoes.

Text:
You probably know that wind and water can shape Earth’s land. But did you know that glaciers can too?
Glaciers are made of ice. Ice is a solid. But glaciers are so large and heavy that they can flow like a river.
Glaciers are found on high mountains. It is cold there, so snow doesn’t melt. Instead, the snow piles up and gets squished together, forming ice. Over many years, the ice builds up and forms a glacier.
The glacier becomes so heavy that it slowly moves down the mountains. The glacier scrapes and shapes the mountains’ sides as it moves.
Glaciers are also found in the Arctic and in Antarctica. They press and grind the land below as they move.
Glaciers have shaped the world in surprising ways. Millions of years ago, glaciers covered the desert of South Africa. The glaciers slowly moved, scraping across the desert’s rocks. Today, we see flat, polished rocks and know that glaciers were once there.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The majority of sentences are simple or compound. Most of the sentences have one concept , and the ones that have multiple concepts only have 2. There are few subordinate/dependent clauses or transitions. The Flesch Kincaid level indicates that it is appropriate for the 2nd-3rd grade text complexity band. Third graders are accustomed to reading and writing simple, compound, and complex sentences and using linking words and phrases, such as the ones used in this text.
ss_annotator_2: This text structure is very uninspiring for a third grade. The sentences hava simple, repetitive structure. There a limited additional concepts to enhance the information. The paragraph structure makes it even more simple. Any form of complexity would be needed to increase the rigor.
ss_annotator_3: The majority of the sentences are simple which allows for comprehension. The sentences that contain multiple concepts are basic enough that third graders can comprehend.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Students would be able to access the gist of this text with no to light scaffolds; vocab is not a barrier
 
vocab_annotator_2: This passage is very good for third-graders, in that it is not too murky, has explainable vocabulary, and concepts that are laid out simply.
vocab_annotator_3: Easy to follow for a 3rd grader
Tier 2 Words: desert, flow, glaciers, grind, piles, polished, scrapes, solid, squished, surprising
Other Complex Words: arctic and in antarctica, south africa
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with the concept of weather and climate, as well as landforms and how they change, but may not be familiar with the specific role of glaciers in shaping Earth's land.

Text:
Julie works at a place called the United States Polar Rock Repository. It is a place that stores rocks from the Arctic and Antarctica. It is a library of rocks! Julie takes pictures of the rocks that are sent there. She writes descriptions of them. She labels each rock so it can be stored. But what she likes the most is sharing the rocks with other people.
This black, crumbly rock from the continent of Antarctica is coal. Coal is a fossil fuel. It is formed from trees and plants that died and fell to the ground. Over millions of years, the plants broke down and became packed together. Over time, the tightly packed plants became coal.
But wait! Why is there coal in Antarctica? There are no trees and not many plants there. Most of Antarctica is a cold, frozen desert.
Julie knows that rocks can tell a story. The coal tells us that Antarctica was very different long ago. There was no ice or snow. Antarctica was warm and covered by swamps and forests.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Of the 20 sentences in this text, 15 are simple or compound. Most of the sentences have just one concept each, and only 4 sentences have 2 concepts each. There are very few subordinate/dependent clauses and transition words. The Flesch Kincaid level falls within the text complexity range for 2nd-3rd grade. All of these items make the text moderately complex and very easy for a third grader to read independently. Third graders have learned to use coordinating and subordinating conjunctions in writing, so they should be able to also read sentences containing those conjunctions. This text only has one, "but," and seems to be written for a much younger audience.
ss_annotator_2: These text structures are getting way to simple. There are a few transitions, but third grade would appreciate less predictably stated ones. Additional structure with additional concepts added would increase the rigor, but that component is absent.
ss_annotator_3: The majority of sentences are simple. Sentence 6 is the first complex sentence that contains two concepts but the sentence has a cause/effect relationship that is simple enough for third graders to follow.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Students would be able to access the gist of this text with no to light scaffolds; vocab is not a barrier
 
vocab_annotator_2: This passage will likely allow the student to access the knowledge easily. The word choice is appropriate and will not challenge a third grader very much.
vocab_annotator_3: Great read for a student at this level.
Tier 2 Words: continent, crumbly, descriptions, formed, fossil fuel, labels, packed, repository, swamps
Tier 3 Words: antarctica, arctic, coal, forests, fossil fuel, swamps
Other Complex Words: arctic and antarctica, united states polar rock repository, united states polar rock repository.
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic concepts of fossils and Earth's changes over time, but may not be familiar with the specific idea of coal formation in Antarctica or the historical climate changes of the continent.

Text:
Blue whales are the largest animals on Earth. They weigh as much as twenty elephants! But they eat very small animals called krill. 
Krill live in the ocean. They are two inches long. They look like shrimp The krill eat plankton that floats in the ocean. The plankton uses the sun’s energy to make food.
Blue whales do not have teeth. Instead, they have bristles called baleen in their mouths. When whales eat, they gulp large mouthfuls of water and krill. The whales squeeze the water back out with their tongues, and the krill is trapped by the baleen. Then the whales swallow the krill. Yum!
The krill eat the plankton. Then the blue whales eat the krill. This is called a food chain. A food chain shows the animals that eat each other.
The Southern Ocean is just right for the plankton, the krill, and the blue whales. It has cold water, nutrients, and lots of sunlight in the summer.
There aren’t many blue whales in the Southern Ocean today. Now there are laws protecting the blue whales, but their numbers are still low.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: This sentence structure is too simple for third and fourth grade. The sentences are SO simple- they are formatted the same way with very little creative part of speech. The concepts are not expanded on within a sentence. This creates a stunted flow of reading for these grades.  The paragraph format and the transitions are very basic- probably frustrating for these eager learners. It actually is worse to read texts like these because its just so boring .
ss_annotator_2: This passage seems more appropriate for a second grader. The sentences are simple and short. The sentences that are complex are still very basic-level.
ss_annotator_3: Sentences are mostly simple and compound.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
The South Pole is much colder than the North Pole. Summer at the South Pole is actually colder than winter at the North Pole! Brr!
Do you know why it is so much colder at the South Pole?
The first reason has to with what is around the poles. The North Pole is over an ice-covered ocean. While that sounds chilly, the water and ice actually keep the temperature from dropping too low.
The South Pole is over land – the continent of Antarctica. Land does not stay as warm as water does. The land is also very high, which means that the air is very cold. Think of very tall mountains. They are always covered in snow, because the air around their peaks is cold. It’s the same thing in Antarctica.
The weather also makes Antarctica colder. Antarctica is far away from other continents, so the cold ocean water and air currents circle the land, keeping the warm air out. The North Pole is much closer to land, so the warmer air can float over the North Pole and warm it up.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: This is far too simple of text structure. A student would likely read the first sentence or two and want to stop reading. They are capable of more complexity in structure, additional concepts in sentence and more complex transitions. This is not close to the rigor that enhanced third grade readers.
ss_annotator_2: Very few sentences have more than one concept and the majority of sentences are simple. The final sentence appears to be the most complex but it is still comprehendable for third graders.
ss_annotator_3: Fourth graders are expected to read informational texts with some embedded clauses and science-specific vocabulary.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Appropriate vocab and structure for 3rd grade
vocab_annotator_2: This student will probably not have much difficulty accessing this new knowledge. The vocabulary is straight forward.
vocab_annotator_3: Easy to follow and understand.
Tier 2 Words: actually, continent, continents, currents, peaks
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic concepts of weather and climate, as well as the idea of continents and oceans. They may not be familiar with the specific reasons for temperature differences between the poles or the concept of air currents affecting climate.

Text:
In the past, Inuit people of northern Canada built igloos and lived in them during the cold winter months. How can a house of ice and snow keep you warm? The ice blocks out the cold wind. Ice is also good at trapping heat from a candle, small fire, or even from your body.
The heat inside an igloo can make the insides of the walls start to melt. But the outside of the walls is still cold. This makes the walls turn from snow into ice. Ice walls are much stronger. A grown man can stand on top of an igloo without it falling down!
How do you build an igloo? An Inuit builder cuts blocks out of well-packed snow and makes a ring of blocks on the ground. Next, he stacks a second row of blocks on top of the first row. The second row is tilted inward just a little bit. This means that he needs fewer blocks for the second row than for the first. He continues stacking blocks and the walls of the igloo grow. He carefully fits the blocks together so they don’t fall. Finally, he places the last block on the very top of the igloo.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Students have appropriate background knowledge to help comprehend this. There is only one typo  (where the apostrophe is supposed to be in don't). Clear sequence of events are laid out in the text. There are clear explanations of how the igloo is built with short, simple sentences in language that is kid-friendly.
ss_annotator_2: 12/17 sentences are simple which provides third graders with the opportunity to read the complex or compound sentences with more focus.
ss_annotator_3: Sentences are mostly short to medium length and clear:

“The ice blocks out the cold wind.”

“He carefully fits the blocks together so they don’t fall.”

Some sentences include cause-and-effect or explanation clauses (e.g., “This makes the walls turn from snow into ice.”), which is good practice for third graders but not overly complex.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Some moths lay eggs in clothing. Others lay them in dry food, like flour or rice. When the eggs hatch, the larvae will then eat the clothing or dried food. In the same way, larvae have damaged crops, trees and ornamental plants. Have you ever found strange holes in your clothes? They might have been made by a hungry moth larva!
Humans use mothballs to keep moths out of their clothing. Mothballs are round, white balls treated with chemicals that poison moths. Since the poison may also harm humans, the balls should never be tasted or eaten. You should wash your hands immediately after touching mothballs.
At the same time, moths also do things which help people. For example, moths help flowers grow by pollinating them. The downside of this is that the moths also lay their eggs in the leaves of the plant. When the eggs hatch into caterpillars, the munching of the plant begins! Have you ever seen the holes that caterpillars make as they chew on the leaves of plants?
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Only two unusual vocabulary terms used: ornamental and maybe larvae. The students should have strong schema to make connections to this piece and assist in comprehension. Simple sentences, no abstract topics or messages. When something new is introduced (mothballs), it is immediately explained in the following sentence. Conversational tone with exclamation and question marks.
ss_annotator_2: There are some complex sentences such as sentence 3. Even though it has two concepts, it the cause and effect relationship is easy to follow. Sentence 9 is also complex but the problem/solution relationship is easy to follow.
ss_annotator_3: Sentences are generally short and clear (“Some moths lay eggs in clothing.”), but a few are compound/complex:
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Seems appropriate for third grade, some vocabulary that is complex, but a subject that a lot of students will have schema
vocab_annotator_2: Most third grade students would have adequate background knowledge and familiarity with these words to be able it interact with the text.
vocab_annotator_3: Easy to follow, not a lot of tier 2 words.
Tier 2 Words: caterpillars, chemicals, crops, damaged, downside, harm, immediately, larva, larvae, mothballs, munching, ornamental, poison, poisons, pollinating, tasted
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic concepts of pollination and plant-animal relationships, but may not be familiar with the specific role of moths in these processes or the use and safety concerns of mothballs.

Text:
What do you do when you hit your knee on a chair? You touch your knee and you rub it, don’t you? Some scientists believe that we rub the hurting body part to reduce the pain. They call this “gate control theory of pain”.
This theory is quite complicated. However, to get an idea of it, imagine again the wires called neurons. There are wires that send pain and others that send the rubbing sensation to the brain. These wires reach the brain via the spinal cord. At some point, both wires meet and pass through a place, which you can think of as a gate. This gate has a certain width that decides which signals can go through. If there is only the pain signal, without the rubbing, the gate will let all of the pain through. However, if you also rub your knee, the gate will let the rubbing signal pass but only part of the pain signal. That is why you reduce the pain if you rub your injured body part
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Typos where apostrophe and quotation marks belong inhibit comprehension and serve as distraction. in the second paragraph, it says "imagine again". Text:
What do you do when you hit your knee on a chair? You touch your knee and you rub it, don’t you? Some scientists believe that we rub the hurting body part to reduce the pain. They call this “gate control theory of pain”.
This theory is quite complicated. However, to get an idea of it, imagine again the wires called neurons. There are wires that send pain and others that send the rubbing sensation to the brain. These wires reach the brain via the spinal cord. At some point, both wires meet and pass through a place, which you can think of as a gate. This gate has a certain width that decides which signals can go through. If there is only the pain signal, without the rubbing, the gate will let all of the pain through. However, if you also rub your knee, the gate will let the rubbing signal pass but only part of the pain signal. That is why you reduce the pain if you rub your injured body part
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Typos where apostrophe and quotation marks belong inhibit comprehension and serve as distraction. in the second paragraph, it says "imagine again". Where was the first instance of imagining? A lot of abstract imagery regarding the workings of the nervous system, about which students are not likely to be knowledgeable. Using abstract explanations for an unknown topic is a recipe for non-comprehension.
ss_annotator_2: The complex sentences have common structures of cause and effect that fourth graders will be able to comprehend.
ss_annotator_3: The passage contains mostly simple and compound sentences, with some complex constructions (e.g., “If there is only the pain signal, without the rubbing, the gate will let all of the pain through.”).
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: moderately complex with subject specific and academic vocab. a fourth grade reader would likely be able to navigate the scientific vocabulary especially given the in-text descriptions. 
vocab_annotator_2: This would be very interesting and relatable to fourth graders. The vocabulary is easy enough for them to understand the ideas within the passage, without getting stuck on comprehending the meaning of the vocabulary words.
vocab_annotator_3: Just a few of the tier 2 words that make it slightly complex
Tier 2 Words: complicated, imagine, injured, neurons, reduce, rubbing, sensation, signals, spinal cord, theory, width
Tier 3 Words: gate control theory, neurons, spinal cord
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic human anatomy and the concept of nerves, but they may not be familiar with the gate control theory of pain or the specific role of neurons in pain transmission.

Text:
At the top of the stomach is a tube where food comes in from the esophagus. When you swallow, this tube opens so food can go in the stomach.
The stomach is made of muscle. These muscles help to break down food by mashing it into smaller pieces. The muscles also make waves pushing the food further down the digestive track. This is called peristalsis and happens from the esophagus all the way to the large intestine.
The stomach is lined with glands. These special cells make a liquid that is released into the stomach. This liquid is called gastric juice. The gastric juice has acid in it and helps break down or digest food.
The bottom part of the stomach is called the pyloric area. At the bottom of the stomach is another opening. This leads to the small intestine.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Students will not know what the esophagus is - there needs to be an explanation of that word. Also, you are factually incorrect in the use of digestive track - it should be digestive tract. The passage needs to be more clear in its explanations. "This is called peristalsis" should really be, "These waves of movement pushing food through the digestive system is called peristalsis." There are numerous instances in this passage where the sentences need to be more clear.
ss_annotator_2: Text is comprised mostly of simple sentences.
ss_annotator_3: The seven sentences with multiple concepts make this slightly too difficult for third graders.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Not too complex, but the words are so academic, I think it is too hard for 3rd
vocab_annotator_2: The text did a good job of defining the difficult vocabulary words in a context that is appropriate for third graders.
vocab_annotator_3: Students at this level would not comprehend the idea that muscles make waves. For independent work, a student would have a lot of questions for the teacher on every sentence.
Tier 2 Words: cells, digest, further, leads, liquid, mashing, muscles, released, stomach, swallow, waves
Tier 3 Words: acid, cells, digest, digestive track, esophagus, gastric juice, glands, intestine, peristalsis, pyloric, pyloric area, small intestine
Other Complex Words: etc., intestine, medical anatomy words such as esophagus, pyloric
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic human body systems and functions, such as digestion, but may not be familiar with specific terms like "peristalsis" and "gastric juice."

Text:
The Sun’s light shines on Earth. The light makes our air, land, and water warm. But some things get
warmer than others.
Pretend it is a sunny day. If you wore a black shirt, you would feel hot. But if you wore a white shirt, you wouldn’t feel as hot. The dark color absorbs more of the Sun’s energy. That makes the black shirt warm.
Light colors reflect more of the Sun’s energy. This makes the white shirt cooler to wear. See for yourself! You need a piece of black paper and a piece of white paper. You also need two thermometers and a lamp. Ask an adult to help you.
Fold the black paper so it makes a pocket. Do the same thing to the white paper. Next, put a thermometer into the black pocket. Do the same thing to the white pocket. Then put the pockets under the lamp. Turn the lamp on, and wait for 10 minutes. Then check the thermometers.
Which pocket got hotter — the black pocket or the white one? Do you know why?
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: More typos where apostrophes belong. Simple topic and the kids would comprehend if the typos are fixed.
ss_annotator_2: The majority of the text is simple sentences with one concept.
ss_annotator_3: There are 18 simple sentences. The first complex sentence is "If you wear a black shirt, you would feel hot." This is a sentence that a third grader could easily comprehend.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Laura Gladstone is a scientist. She works in Antarctica. Antarctica is a place at the bottom of the world. Do you know what it is like there? 
It is cold. Laura needed warm clothes to work there.
It is too cold to grow food. There are no stores there. Planes bring food to the scientists.
One day, the scientists made ice cream by mixing milk and water. Then they left the bowls outside. The ice cream froze!
The scientists have to save water and fuel. They can only take a few short showers a week.
Laura wore pants, a sweatshirt, and a hat to sleep. She used three blankets and her coat to keep warm!
It doesn’t get dark at night in the summer there. The sun never sets. So Laura wore a mask over her eyes. The mask kept out the sunlight.
The scientists work hard. But they have fun, too. Every year they have a race around the South Pole. 
Laura worked at the South Pole. There aren’t any animals there. So Laura’s stuffed penguin, PJ, kept her company. 
Laura liked working in Antarctica. Would you like to work there someday?
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: The whole text consists of simple sentences with only one concept.
ss_annotator_2: The text is entirely to simple in structure as well as concepts. They are mainly very short and simple sentences. The concepts are very basic and there are not added depth with complexity. It is so choppy to due to the short basic sentences. Additionally there a not enough additional parts of speech that create some depth to the concepts.  It is much to primary for third grade.
ss_annotator_3: There are only simple sentences and only one concept per sentence. This is very easy.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Have you ever gone for a walk in the woods? If you have, you may have seen colorful things growing on tree trunks and rocks. They look like plants, but they aren’t. They are called lichens. Lichens are made of two living things: a fungus and an alga. They live together and help each other.
How do these living things help each other? The alga makes food from air and water. The fungus protects the alga by growing around it.
Lichens have no roots. They don’t need soil to grow. They can grow in strange places—on rocks, cliffs, and tree trunks. In the Arctic and Antarctica, lichens grow on rocks.
Lichens grow slowly. They can grow in cold temperatures. They can even keep growing when covered in snow!
Lichens are tough. If a lichen gets dry and cold, it might crumble and blow away in the wind. But it isn’t dead. When it is warmer or wetter, the lichen might start growing again.
Lichens are important. Caribou eat them in the winter. People use them to make dyes and medicines. Scientists study how they can warn us about pollution.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: There are several complex sentences in the text as well as several sentences that contain multiple concepts.
ss_annotator_2: Although there are some text complexity in structure and additional concepts, there are very minimal. It is more interesting than some of the previous text passages due to the main structure of how the words are used and having some additional parts of speech. But overall, there are far too many simple sentences. Third grade would benefit from some additional concepts told through sentence complexity.
ss_annotator_3: 7 of the sentences are complex but are basic. "If you have, you may have seen colorful things growing on tree trunks and rocks." This is a sentence structure familiar to third grade students.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Lichen might throw third graders, but I think it's used so often they can figure it out with context clues. A third grader might not know what a caribou is depending on where they live, but could assume it's an animal because it eats, so once again context clues help with comprehension
vocab_annotator_2: I believe with the background knowledge given above, a third grader will be able to comprehend this material.
vocab_annotator_3: Grade-Level Appropriateness: Appropriate for Grade 3 independent reading. Simple, straightforward. Mostly short sentences, clear transitions. 
 
 Vocabulary Complexity: Mix of Tier 2 and Tier 3 words. The Tier 3 science words are high for Grade 3 but manageable because of context support.
Tier 2 Words: caribou, colorful, crumble, dyes, pollution, protect(s), protects, scientists, strange, tough, warn
Tier 3 Words: alga, antarctica, arctic, caribou, dyes, fungus, lichens, medicines, roots, scientists
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic plant and animal relationships and environments, but may not be familiar with the specific symbiotic relationship between fungi and algae in lichens.

Text:
Have you heard of the Arctic? It is a place at the top of the world. Many animals live on the land and in the water there.
One of these animals is the arctic wolf. It is a wolf with snowy white fur. Imagine that you are a wolf. What would your life be like?
You would live with your mother, father, brothers and sisters in a group. This group is called a pack. Other wolves would live in the pack, too.
You would like to play with your brothers and sisters. This would teach you how to hunt. Your pack would hunt together. You might hunt caribou, rabbits, and musk oxen.
Your life would be hard. Hunting is dangerous. You might not be able to find food. Then you would be hungry.
You would be cold and hungry during the winter. You would huddle with the other wolves to stay warm.
But summer would be different. There would be plenty of animals to hunt. Then you could sleep in the warm sunlight with your packmates. Zzzzz…
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Most of the text contains simple sentences with only one concept.

ss_annotator_2: These text passages are really simple in this set. There are simple text structure, singular concepts, and no subordinate clauses or interesting transitions. The sentences are short with limited word choice. This is far too easy for third and fourth grade.

ss_annotator_3: There is only one sentence with multiple concepts which is that animals live on land and water. This is a concept that is very easy for third graders to comprehend.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Near the top of the world is land called tundra. The tundra is flat and has no trees. It is covered by snow and ice most of the year. 
In the spring, the snow and ice melt. Beneath the ground, the soil stays frozen. The ground gets very soggy. It is a marsh.
Small yellow flowers grow from the cold, wet ground. They are called marsh marigolds.
Flies hide in the flowers. They soak up the Sun’s energy and get warm.
The flies fly from flower to flower. They help the flowers make seeds.
Caribou eat the flowers. The caribou also give the plants the nutrients they need to grow.
Mother flies lay their eggs inside the caribou’s nose. It is warm there. The young flies eat and grow.
The young flies get bigger. AH-CHOO! The caribou sneezes. The flies land on the ground. Soon, they will be adults.
These plants and animals need each other. Can you think of others?
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Very appropriate. Short and simple sentences make independent reading and comprehension possible. The conversational elements and humor will also make it easy to follow.

ss_annotator_2: Most of the text consists of simple sentences and a couple of complex sentences that contain multiple concepts.

ss_annotator_3: 19/23 sentences are simple. The complex sentence is basic and does not require a high level of thinking to understand.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: Some complex words but a low ratio. Fine for the age. 

vocab_annotator_2: This passage is more appropriate for grade 2.

vocab_annotator_3: Grade-Level Appropriateness: Yes‚ this text is reasonable for Grade 3 independent readers. Mostly simple and short sentences. Clear cause-effect relationships. Vocabulary Complexity: Most words are Tier 1. Complex words add challenge but are still approachable in context.
Tier 2 Words: adults, beneath, energy, environments, marsh, nutients, nutrients, relationships, soggy, soil
Tier 3 Words: caribou, ecosystems, marigold, marigolds, marsh, permafrost, tundra

Text:
When you think of dinosaurs and where they lived, what do you picture? Do you see hot, steamy swamps, thick jungles, or sunny plains? Dinosaurs lived in those places, yes. But did you know that some dinosaurs lived in the cold and the darkness near the North and South Poles?
This surprised scientists, too. Paleontologists used to believe that dinosaurs lived only in the warmest parts of the world. They thought that dinosaurs could only have lived in places where turtles, crocodiles, and snakes live today. Later, these dinosaur scientists began finding bones in surprising places.
One of those surprising fossil beds is a place called Dinosaur Cove, Australia. One hundred million years ago, Australia was connected to Antarctica. Both continents were located near the South Pole. Today, paleontologists dig dinosaur fossils out of the ground. They think about what those ancient bones must mean.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Appropriate with some teacher support. Passage includes a mixture of simple, compound, and complex sentences. The sentences are sequential and easy to follow.

ss_annotator_2: The text contains several complex sentences and sentences with multiple concepts.

ss_annotator_3: There are four sentences with multiple concepts which is why I rated it as moderately complex. This seems very appropriate for an early third grade text level.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
The whole universe is built of matter. Right now, you are surrounded by it. The air we breathe is matter, and all the things you see around you are matter. The odors you smell are matter and the sounds you hear are caused by the movement of matter in your ears.
Matter is everything that takes up space and has weight. Scientists say that matter has volume and mass. Matter is made up of tiny building blocks called atoms. The purest type of atom is called an element. The elements are what give matter its different qualities.
Today we can see atoms by using a special instrument called an electron microscope. An electron microscope lets us see things that are millions of times smaller than the things we can see with a powerful optical microscope.
Most of the matter around us has more than one element in it. But some matter is made up of just one element. If you have ever held a diamond, for example, it is made of just one element, Carbon.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: This will be slightly challenging due to some of the compound sentences. It can be read independently with moderate ease.

ss_annotator_2: The text contains several complex sentences and sentences with multiple concepts.

ss_annotator_3: Third graders may struggle with the complex and compound sentences.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: some complex terms related to the subject and academic in nature. given the sentence complexity, reasonably accessible vocab, and given background knowledge a third grader would likely be able to read and comprehend independently

vocab_annotator_2: The sentence structure, vocabulary, and topic are appropriate for grade 3.

vocab_annotator_3: Grade-Level Appropriateness: Reasonable to use for grade 3 independent work. Most sentences are straightforward, declarative, and concrete. Accessible for independent reading. Vocabulary Complexity: Text is on the upper end of Grade 3 independent reading. Some Tier 3 words may give pause to some readers.

Text:
The whole universe is built of matter. Right now, you are surrounded by it. The air we breathe is matter, and all the things you see around you are matter. The odors you smell are matter and the sounds you hear are caused by the movement of matter in your ears.
Matter is everything that takes up space and has weight. Scientists say that matter has volume and mass. Matter is made up of tiny building blocks called atoms. The purest type of atom is called an element. The elements are what give matter its different qualities.
Today we can see atoms by using a special instrument called an electron microscope. An electron microscope lets us see things that are millions of times smaller than the things we can see with a powerful optical microscope.
Most of the matter around us has more than one element in it. But some matter is made up of just one element. If you have ever held a diamond, for example, it is made of just one element, Carbon.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Appropriate for grade 4 due to the experience with all sentence types. Sentences are clear and easy to follow.

ss_annotator_2: The text contains several complex sentences and sentences with multiple concepts.

ss_annotator_3: There are enough simple sentences to sustain comprehension for fourth graders throughout the passage. The rest of the complex or compound sentences are enough of an attainable challenge for fourth graders.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
So what is a solid? Solids are usually hard because their molecules have been packed together. The closer your molecules are, the harder you are. Solids also can hold their own shape. A rock will always look like a rock unless something happens to it. The same goes for a diamond. Even when you grind up a solid into a powder, you will see tiny little pieces of that solid under a microscope. Liquids will move and fill up any container. Solids keep their shape.
In the same way that a solid holds its shape, the atoms inside of a solid are not allowed to move around too much. This is one of the physical characteristics of solids. Atoms and molecules in liquids and gases are bouncing and floating around, free to move where they want. The molecules in a solid are stuck in place. The atoms still spin and the electrons will still fly around, but the entire atom will not change position.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Slightly challenging for grade 3 students because of the longer compound sentences and dependent clauses within the sentences.

ss_annotator_2: The text contains many complex sentences as well as many sentences with multiple concepts.

ss_annotator_3: The first paragraph is easy enough for third graders but the second paragraph contains complex and compound sentences that would break down comprehension.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: VCS: I think the use of specific vocabulary in this text - namely "hold", "fill up", and "keep"- is a critical inhibitor of comprehension. These three words/phrases are used in ways counter to their colloquial definitions that an average on-grade-level third grader would be familiar with. Without understanding the different meanings of these words in this passage, it's very difficult for a student to comprehend the text and formulate the central idea. 

vocab_annotator_2: This content are passage is appropriate for grade 3.

vocab_annotator_3: Grade-Level Appropriateness: Appropriate for Grade 3 independent reading. Sentences are mostly short to medium in length, straightforward, with a few slightly complex constructions. Vocabulary Complexity: Most Tier 2 words are appropriate for Grade 3, although some Tier 3 scientific terms may be unfamilair.
Tier 2 Words: characteristics, closely, container, gases, grind, liquid, molecules, packed, physical, position, solid, usually
Tier 3 Words: atoms, diamond, electrons, microscope, molecules, physical characteristics
Other Complex Words: fill up, fly, gases, grind, hold, holds, keep, liquids, powder, solids, spin
Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with the basic properties of solids, liquids, and gases, including the concept that solids hold their shape and have closely packed molecules. They may not be familiar with the detailed behavior of atoms and electrons within solids.

Text:
The name Monarch means “king”. An adult Monarch Butterfly is about 1 ½ inches long. Its body is black with white markings. There are white spots on the head and around the wing edges. The wings are bright orange with black veins. The undersides of the wings are light orange. Male Monarchs have a black spot on the back of each hind wing.
Wings have 2 parts: a forewing and a hind wing. The wing span can be up to 4 inches across. The back edges of the wings are called “margins”. They bend to push air backward and move the butterfly forward. The stiff front edges of the wings lift the butterfly in flight. Black veins create a framework that keeps the wings stable. Female wing veins are thicker than those of males.
Monarch Butterflies come from yellow, black, and white striped caterpillars. Monarch caterpillars grow to about 2 inches in length. They have 2 tentacles that look like antennae at the front of the body, and 2 tentacles at the back.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Very appropriate. Clear short sentences make it easier to read.

ss_annotator_2: Almost the entire text consists of simple sentences that contain one concept.

ss_annotator_3: There are all simple sentences and only two sentences contain multiple concepts.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Walking Sticks are long, thin, and slow-moving bugs, that looks like a stick, twig or branch. They are also called walking sticks. Males tend to be smaller than females. The colors are usually brown or green, but may be grey or shades of red. Also some are shaded orange, but in little places. Stripes, spots, and speckles are more common than solid. Males usually have wings, but females are most likely wingless. Short, tough forewings protect the larger fan-shaped hind wings.
The common American Walking Stick is slender and shiny with long antennas. The adult male is 2 to 3 inches long with bands of color,while the adult female is 4 to 5 inches long.
The New Guinea Spiny Stick Insect is big and bulky. It can grow to 4-1/2 inches to 6 inches long. It resembles a branch more than a slender stick. The colors are dark brown to black. Their legs are thick and prickly. Adult males have a long thorn on each hind leg. Nymphs, another type new type of walking stick, have green-and-brown patterns.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: Very appropriate. Sentences are short and easy to follow. Te passage is full of simple sentences with some coordinating conjunctions.

ss_annotator_2: The text contains some compound sentences as well as sentences with multiple concepts.

ss_annotator_3: There are mostly simple sentences but 6 of the sentences have more than one concept so that makes it moderately complex.
Vocabulary Score Rationale: not scored
Tier 2 Words: not scored
Background Knowledge Assumption: not scored

Text:
Animals are made of many cells. They eat things and digest them inside. Most animals can move. Only animals have brains (though not even all animals do; jellyfish, for example, do not have brains).
Animals are found all over the earth. They dig in the ground, swim in the oceans, and fly in the sky.
Humans are a type of animal. So are dogs, cats, cows, horses, frogs, fish, and so on and on.
Animals can be divided into two main groups, vertebrates and invertebrates. Vertebrates can be further divided into mammals, fish, birds, reptiles, and amphibians. Invertebrates can be divided into arthropods (like insects, spiders, and crabs), mollusks, sponges, several different kinds of worms, jellyfish — and quite a few other subgroups. There are at least thirty kinds of invertebrates, compared to the five kinds of vertebrates. Vertebrates have a backbone, while invertebrates do not.
Sentence Score Rationale:
ss_annotator_1: This text would be slightly challenging for a 3rd grader because of the sentences that include lists and multiple topics being explained in one sentence.

ss_annotator_2: The text contains sentences that have multiple concepts.

ss_annotator_3: Even though the text has 11 simple sentences, there are 5 sentences with multiple concepts which makes it more difficult for third graders.
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
vocab_annotator_1: VCS: There is an even balance of Tier 2 and Tier 3 words in this text, and it's not unreasonable, despite the Tier 3 words in this text, to expect that an average on-grade-level third grader should be able comprehend this text (but may be slowed down at times by the importance of the relative size difference of invertebrate and vertebrate groups as well as their morphology)

vocab_annotator_2: Despite having quite a few tier 3 words, the text is straightforward. The student should be able to access this new information without too much difficulty.

vocab_annotator_3: Grade-Level Appropriateness: Reasonable for Grade 3 independent reading. Mostly short, declarative, accessible sentences. Vocabulary Complexity: Grade 4 appropriate for independent reading. Vocabulary complexity is moderate, mostly due to Tier 3 words.

Text: I had often wondered what became of this highly interesting young woman, and when I began to write "The White Morning" she popped into my mind. I believe she could be a leader of some kind if she chose. Perhaps she is. The cases could be multiplied indefinitely. The Erkels and Mimi Brandt are drawn, together with their conditions, almost photographically. "Heloise" finally married a Scot and went with him to his own country, but her sisters were dragging out their tragic lives when I left Munich. A few days ago I met a highly intelligent American woman of German blood who, before the war, used to visit her relatives in Germany every year. I told her that I had written this story and she agreed with me that it was on the cards the women would instigate a revolution. "Never," she said, "in any country have I known such discontent among women, heard so many bitter confidences. Their feelings against their fathers or husbands were the more intense and violent because they dared not speak out like English or American women."

Text:
When astronauts go on spacewalks, they wear spacesuits to keep themselves safe. Inside spacesuits, astronauts have the oxygen they need to breathe. They have the water they need to drink.
Astronauts put on their spacesuits several hours before a spacewalk. The suits are pressurized. This means that the suits are filled with oxygen.
Once in their suits, astronauts breathe pure oxygen for a few hours. Breathing only oxygen gets rid of all the nitrogen in an astronaut's body. If they didn't get rid of the nitrogen, the astronauts might get gas bubbles in their body when they walked in space. These gas bubbles can cause astronauts to feel pain in their shoulders, elbows, wrists and knees. This pain is called getting "the bends" because it affects the places where the body bends, Scuba divers can also get "the bends."
Astronauts are now ready to get out of their spacecraft. They leave the spacecraft through a special door called an airlock. The airlock has two doors.

Text: This valley, two or three miles broad, stretches unbroken between low hills, softly undulating, crowned with oaks, maples, and birches. Although strewn with wild-flowers in the spring, it looks severe, grave, and sometimes even sad. The green grass imparts to it a monotony like that of stagnant water. Even on fine days one is conscious of a hard, cold climate. The sky seems more genial than the earth. It beams upon it with a tearful smile; it constitutes all the movement, the grace, the exquisite charm of this delicate tranquil landscape. Then when winter comes the sky merges with the earth in a kind of chaos. Fogs come down thick and clinging. The white light mists, which in summer veil the bottom of the valley, give place to thick clouds and dark moving mountains, but slowly scattered by a red, cold sun. Wanderers ranging the uplands in the early morning might dream with the mystics in their ecstasy that they are walking on clouds.

Text:
Tides are the rise and fall of sea levels caused by the combined effects of the gravitational forces exerted by the Moon and the Sun and the rotation of the Earth.
The times and amplitude of tides at a locale are influenced by the alignment of the Sun and Moon, by the pattern of tides in the deep ocean, by the amphidromic systems of the oceans, and the shape of the coastline and near-shore bathymetry (see Timing). Some shorelines experience a semi-diurnal tide - two nearly equal high and low tides each day. Other locations experience a diurnal tide - only one high and low tide each day. A "mixed tide"; two uneven tides a day, or one high and one low, is also possible.
Tides vary on timescales ranging from hours to years due to a number of factors. To make accurate records, tide gauges at fixed stations measure the water level over time. Gauges ignore variations caused by waves with periods shorter than minutes. These data are compared to the reference (or datum) level usually called mean sea level.
Sentence Score Rationale: not scored
Vocabulary Score Rationale:

Background Knowledge Assumption: Students are likely familiar with basic concepts of the Moon, Sun, and Earth's rotation from topics like "Outer Space" and "Weather and Climate," but may not be familiar with specific terms like "amphidromic systems" or "bathymetry."

Text:
I have my machine nearly finished. It is not to have a motor and is not expected to fly any true sense of the word. My idea is merely to experiment and practice with a view to solving the problem of equilibrium. I have plans which I hope to find much in advance of the methods tried by previous experimenters. When once a machine is under proper control under all conditions, the motor problem will be quickly solved. A failure of motor will then simply mean a slow descent and safe landing instead of a disastrous fall.
In my experiments I do not expect to rise many feet from the ground, and in case I am upset there is nothing but soft sand to strike on. I do not intend to take dangerous chances, both because I have no wish to get hurt and because a fall would stop my experimenting, which I would not like at all. The man who wishes to keep at the problem long enough to really learn anything positively cannot take dangerous risks.
Sentence Score Rationale: not scored
Vocabulary Score Rationale:
